Brexiteers will undoubtedly want a credible Leave option, possibly no deal, while pro-EU campaigners will demand&nbspthe chance to stay in the EU on the ballot.I haven't marched for 50 years – but I will for a Final Say on BrexitStudent leaders sign letter urging May to hold Final Say referendum Celebrities fund transport to Brexit protest for new EU referendumHere’s how Theresa May can get around Bercow’s dramatic Brexit rulingThe people will have a Final Say on Brexit. It's inevitableTo trigger a Final Say referendum, the government would need to support the plan. Ms May has always been firm in her opposition to another public vote – but the public will remember she&nbspbroke her promise not to hold a general election in 2017. She is also running out of options to resolve the Brexit crisis.One scenario could see Ms May offer a second referendum to MPs in exchange for supporting her Brexit deal. Labour MPs Phil Wilson and Peter Kyle have worked up an amendment for a “confirmatory vote”, where approval of the prime minister’s deal in the Commons would be conditional on throwing the question to the public.The Kyle-Wilson plan, as it is known, was drawn up in consultation with Jeremy Corbyn’s frontbench, suggesting it could secure that all-important Labour support in the Commons.It&nbspmight&nbspovercome speaker John Bercow’s ruling that the prime minister cannot bring back her deal without “substantial changes”. Her Brexit plan would certainly look different if it had a second referendum attached to it.Another scenario gaining momentum in Westminster is indicative votes. These would test the will of parliament by giving MPs a series of non-binding votes on their preferred Brexit options.It is expected to come to a head on Monday when cross-party backbenchers, led by Labour’s Hilary Benn, attempt to seize control of the Commons timetable to allow for indicative votes on Wednesday.Downing Street is understood to be considering seven different options for the votes, including the prime minister’s deal, a second referendum, a no-deal Brexit or the deal plus membership of a customs union and single market.If a second referendum wins&nbspa large backing, then the prime minister will be forced to give serious consideration to the prospect.We’ll tell you what’s true. title: national living wage uk 2019 budget 2018 increase minimum wage 16 18 25 year olds
story: But Chancellor Philip Hammond has announced a further increase for some workers from .The National Living Wage is the amount of money all employees aged over  are legally entitled to.It used to be known as the National Minimum Wage, but it was re-branded in .The National Living Wage increased from £. to £. for those aged  and over.The  pence-an-hour rise was introduced on Sunday April , .From April , the National Living Wage will increase by  pence-an-hour to £..The compulsory National Living Wage was introduced in .The first National Minimum Wage was set in  by the Labour government.Before that, no official rate existed although trade unions battled hard to fight their workers corner.In Budget , Chancellor Hammond announced that lowest-paid workers will get another pay rise from next year to a minimum of £. per hour.Its a five per cent hike, which will come into force from April, and will benefit around .million workers.Mr Hammond said: From April [the National Living Wage] will rise again, handing a full-time worker a £ annual pay increase.Hammond is aiming to get the wage to £ by .It is dferent to the real living wage which is voluntary and not fixed by the government.The National Minimum Wage is the amount workers aged under , but of school-leaving age, are entitled to.However, the amount dfers depending on age and whether the worker is on an apprenticeship scheme.From April  the rate for National Living Wage and National Minimum Wage is:From April  the rate for National Living Wage and National Minimum Wage will be:The national limits are legally binding.Anyone who thinks they are not getting the National Living Wage or National Minimum Wage should complain to their employer in the first instance.If this does not get anywhere, the next step is to take the complaint to HMRC who will investigate.Those who are self-employed, voluntary workers, company directors and family members who live in the home of the employer and do household chores do not qualy for either rate.There is no dference in pay for those that live in London compared to where.The only discrepancy is for people working in agriculture or horticulture.Workers already employed before October , , are entitled to the pay set under their contract of employment.

title: worlds craziest houses
story: But some homeowners have gone all out with their property - here we have pulled together ten of the most outrageous houses from all over the world.Dubbed the Heliodome, this house in France has been described as the “ultimate solar architecture”.Its eye-catching design - constructed by a cabinet maker - is not just for a unique look but to capture the maximum amount of solar rays as possible.It provides free heating in the winter and cools down the house in the summer.But although it is an eco-friendly way of producing heat, many locals have complained about it’s look saying it doesn’t fit in with the French countryside.The giant seashell house is a joy to look at - with dozens of coloured mosaics that light up the indoors living space.The multicoloured house is in Mexico City and was built in .It is full of plants and natural light after being carefully designed but has all the features to make it a modern home.Despite its unusual shape it was designed to fit in with the natural surrounding and make the occupants feel like they were immersed in the wilderness.This WC-shaped house is made from steel, white concrete and glass, with a suggestive opening in the roof.It is in Seoul, South Korea, and continues the bathroom theme as it is full of toilets.The toilet house was built by Sim Jae-duck, chairman of the organising committee of the Inaugural General Assembly of the World Toilet Association.It is called “Haewoojae” which means “a place of sanctuary where one can solve one’s worries” in Korean.The upside down house is in Affoldern, Germany, and took only six weeks to build.It cost about €, and has an interior which is very disorientating to visitors.It was build in the village near the Edersee Lake in , and comes complete with bedrooms, a kitchen and bathroom.Every item, including crockery, a bath, knives and a toilet, is glued to the ceiling.Star Trek fans can live in a replica of the Voyager, complete with out of this world lighting and decor.The studio flat in Hinckley, Leicestershire, has been lovingly decked out with the main commands control.No detail has been overlooked in the m flat in the Midlands.It went on sale in  for £,.The Keret House in Warsaw, Poland, was the world’s narrowest house when it was built in .The tiny structure is squeezed in between two other buildings and has been described as more of an art installation.Apparently not as claustrophobic as it looks at cms at its widest point, a long ladder takes the occupant up through ious rooms, which look more like shelves.It was planned to be a temporary home for travelling writers.This snappy home is the work of an artist who died two months before it was completed.The crocodile house in the middle of Abidjan, Ivory Coast, is completely hollow.It was completed in  and is now lived in by Thierry Atta, who helped to build it.With windows and a bedroom the unique home is completely liveable and is a popular meeting place for many people in the neighbourhood.This lonely house was built in the middle of a river in .It is perched on a small rock near the Serbian town of Bajina Basta.It was built by a group of young men who thought the rock would be the best place for a tiny shelter, after they needed to rest while out swimming.The man who lives there today was part of the group and has seen off floods and high winds in his little home.One of the strangest homes in the world is one shaped like a giant glittering grand piano and a violin.It is in Huainan, China, and was built in .It features a glass violin propped up against the huge piano, which is the entrance to the house.The piano has a roof terrace beneath a canopy shaped like it’s open top.

title: mps vote theresa mays deal brexit slipping hardliners chasing fantasy
story: Brexit is slipping away.It risks being killed off entirely by the very MPs who claim to love it the most — Conservative backbench Eurosceptics still chasing ­fantasy Brexits.Since last week, the options have changed.First, Parliament voted to rule out No Deal. Then MPs backed a Brexit delay.It’s asthe House of Commons is ­following Tony Blair’s step-by-step guide to overturning the  referendum.A No Deal Brexit will only happen in nine days’ timethe EU refuses an ­extension. That is unlikely.Theresa May will beg for a delay, whatever the conditions.EU members will not want to be blamed for a messy No Deal outcome.From next week, MPs could start voting on their preferred Brexit options through so-called indicative votes. Spoiler alert — they will not end up backing a harder exit.I know there are Leave voters who do not like Theresa May’s Brexit deal.Butyou do not like her deal, look at the alternative options for softer Brexits, which would be far worse for the country.If you think this deal risks the UK ­getting stuck in a customs union, just wait till you see what the deal would look like with Labour’s “permanent” customs union glued on top.Better to have an imperfect route to controlling our own trade policy than no route at all.If you do not like the fact that, under the PM’s deal, we would have to keep existing EU goods and agricultural rules, imagine staying in the Single Market or, as it is rebranded, Common Market .. We would lose the veto over goods rules which we have in the backstop, and be forced to follow rules on services too.Even in a worst-case scenario, Theresa May’s deal lets us escape the EU’s “ever closer union” political project and seize control of our own immigration policy.We would be in control of almost all our economy and not have to pay a penny for it on an ongoing basis.It is far better than most critics will admit. Thanks to changes secured at Strasbourg last week, we have new protections.The EU can no longer do what French President Macron arrogantly threatened. It will not be able to use the backstop as a “trap” to demand access to UK fishing waters.The EU cannot just say “non” to every sensible idea for resolving the Irish border issues. The so-called Star Chamber of MPs were quick to reject the Strasbourg changes.But they should listen to the Irish opposition party.Their Brexit spokesperson said: “We have come a long way” from a “bullet-proof, rock-solid, cast-iron backstop”.Or how about top barrister Lord ­Pannick  He is the QC who won the case for Gina Miller against the Government.He argues that in some circumstances the UK could terminate the deal through the so-called Vienna Convention.Conservative Eurosceptic big beasts, from ex-leader Michael Howard to former Chancellor Norman Lamont, have all weighed in behind the deal.David Davis, who resigned over ­Chequers, is now onside.Lord Trimble, who won the Nobel Peace Prize for the Good Friday Agreement, has backed it. If he can live with the backstop, that should count for something.But some Eurosceptic back- benchers still refuse to support the PM’s deal.Led by Jacob Rees-Mogg, they would prefer a harder deal. But face facts. There is no harder Brexit on offer.With No Deal out of reach, there is no incentive for the EU to provide any more concessions.That means the choices are this deal or a softer Brexit. Or no Brexit at all.And be sure that the Speaker, John Bercow, will bend every possible rule to frustrate Brexit.So, do not expect a long delay to offer a better answer.Anyway, the choice on our future could be made soon.There is no time to lose to save Brexit. Even a snap General Election offers no easy salvation. It would mean Theresa May leading the Tories into another campaign on a manesto of her deal — precisely what her critics want to avoid. And of course, the Conservatives could lose any path to power at all, kissing goodbye to any Brexit.Brexit would never have happenedit had not been for Boris Johnson.Now he has a crucial opportunity to save the whole project.He can show how he can be a ­statesman, by compromising in the national interest.And he can demonstrate the sort of leadership that won him so much praise as Mayor of London.If the Government can persuade the DUP to vote for the deal, backbenchers including Dominic Raab, Iain Duncan Smith, Theresa Villiers and Mark Harper should follow suit.Otherwise, they risk being remembered as the MPs who wrecked Brexit, along with Labour MPs who helped trigger ­Article  and then opposed both No Deal and the current deal.Theresa May also needs to recognise that backbenchers want someone  to take forward the next stage of the negotiations.If she tries to cling to power, critics on both sides of the Brexit ide may never back her deal.Whereasshe pledges to step down on getting her deal through, she can step down as a hero who delivered Brexit against the odds.MPs should know that politics is about taking the world as you find it, not as you would like it to be.And leadership is about taking decisions, even when all the choices are unpalatable.It is fine to stick to principle, but notthat means emulating King Canute’s stand against the waves.If Brexit does not happen it will be a ­national democratic calamity.As the party in power, the Conservatives will be punished.That means risking ­letting Jeremy Corbyn — a leader who can not even deal with anti-Semitism in his own party — seize control of the country.The stakes simply could not be higher. If this chance is squandered we will likely never get another moment.Right across Europe, critics of Brussels will think “even Britain couldn’t break free”.Henry Newman is director of the Open Europe think tank.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: johnny mercer conservative leadership race rules
story: Johnny Mercer wants Conservative MPs to pick four candidates for the party’s wider membership to pick from, not just the current two.Today’s limit allows grandees to fix the outcome and it will chain it to years more Brexit obsessing, the Army officer-turned-MP argues.The intervention comes as speculation mounts that a new race for the Tory crown is imminent, with the Brexit crisis leaving Theresa May’s days in No numbered.Picking just two candidates will “inevitably lead to a Brexit and a Remain candidate”, Mr Mercer has insisted - dubbing that “the two issues most of us cannot wait to move on from”.It also only encourages “grubby deal-making” and MPs being “bought off’ with offers of good jobs.Instead, the party should carry out a modernisation and send double the number out to its , members across the country, the Plymouth MP said – claiming the move will also ignite far wider public interest.In an article today for the Conservative Home website, he added: “With two candidates the whole contest will be about Brexit.“Far too many of our members have become frustrated with this all-pervasive process, and will remain desperately uninspired.“Instead there is a huge opportunity coming shortly to have a genuine and engaging public discussion of what modern Conservatism actually looks like beyond Brexit.”Mr Mercer – tipped as a future leader himself - added: “MP’s should select down to the last four, not two.“Then our membership surely must have their properly weighted say – in a single transferable voting contest.”The current rules were drawn up  years ago by then Tory leader William Hague.Until then, only Tory MPs had a vote on picking their boss. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: take what we can on brexit and scarper
story: This is according to the World Happiness Report.While the rest of the world is sinking into psychological depression, we’re much more upbeat.Some of the British Press reporting this have used those dread words: “Despite Brexit . . . ”It wouldn’t occur to them that it might be BECAUSE of Brexit.I suspect for  per cent of us that’s pretty much the case. Maybe to keep up levels of national happiness we should leave horrible, authoritarian bureaucracies every year. Just to put a grin on our faces. I mean, the French don’t seem very happy, do they But here’s the bad news. Theresa May is still Prime Minister and we’re currently heading for a Brexit which would be a travesty of the one we voted for in . If we get Brexit at all.Some of the Brexiteers in Parliament think we might still be able to escape the EU with a No Deal, on World Trade Organisation terms. I think they are deluding themselves.Parliament, which is two to one in favour of NOT leaving the EU, simply will not let it happen.And the EU, desperate to retain its market for goods in the UK, will make sure it doesn’t happen, too.Our Brexiteers are right that Theresa May’s deal is awful. Butthey get a chance to vote on it again, they should hold their noses and vote in favour.Because I reckon it’s that or nothing. We will have a delay, the EU may insist we hold a second referendum as a condition of that delay.And trust me, the second referendum will be rigged in favour of remaining in the EU. It will not be a straightforward in or out option. There will be three options, to split the Leave vote down the middle.In this fight to leave the EU, the British people have had everything against them. The EU, obvs. But also the House of Commons and the puffed-up, ludicrous, pro-Remain speaker John Bercow. And the House of Lords, the civil service and the BBC.The lesson for us low-born, powerless Leavers is to take what we can and scarper before the whole idea is killed stone dead. Which I fear it may be.And now Mrs May is heading back to Brussels to plead for a delay in triggering Article .All along she has been too obsessed with the process of leaving the EU, rather than the clear imperative as demanded by the British people — to simply LEAVE the EU, all of it.She has followed Brussels’ agenda at every twist and turn. And she’ll be following it now. She’ll do what the EU wants.So here’s the deal, as I see it. Give her hopeless proposal one more chance and this time vote for it.We will have been cheated, but not as badly aswe do not leave at all.Because the longer this goes on, the more likely that outcome will be.THIS country becomes more deranged by the very hour.A Roman Catholic journalist claims she may face JAIL because she referred to a transgendered person by the sex assigned at birth, rather than the one she now identies as.Caroline Farrow has been told she must attend a police station for a taped interview.She said: “I have pointed out to police that I am a Catholic journalist commentator and it is my religious belief that a person cannot change sex.”Quite. Biologists would argue exactly the same.When is this madness going to stop And don’t the Old Bill have better things to do with their time Why should this be  Are they simply delighted they’re not Swedish Other stats might give us a clue.Finland also has one of the highest rates of alcoholism in the world. And also one of the higher suicide rates.So they rate highly for happiness because a they’re all perpetually p***ed b the sad ones have all topped themselves.GORGEOUS, pouting Olivia Attwood has been complaining that reality TV stars are prone to mental illness because of the horrible abuse they get online.Perhaps she’s right. There are some nasty t***ers out there, for sure.But might it not also be the case that reality TV stars are prone to mental illness anyway, without the trolls Being famous just for the sake of being famous appeals to a certain kind of rather fragile, insecure personality, I would reckon.THE Oxford English Dictionary has been updated to include the usual raft of gender words. Such as “zir” and “hir” and the horrible “peoplekind”.I hope they have room next year for these following words I’ve just made up: Togerov – a Bulgarian man who has transitioned to female.Abbottophobia – the irrational fear that Diane is about to appear on the TV talking complete b******s.Droll – an internet troll who is nonetheless quite funny.WYLFWTS– someone on a gender studies or media studies course. From the acronym Would You Like Fries With That, Sir IT is time to sort out the gamekeepers – once and for all.A new study has suggested that they are responsible for the illegal killing of one of Britain’s rarest birds, the hen harrier.These scumbags are believed to have killed almost THREE QUARTERS of tagged hen harriers. The killings take place on grouse moors.These moors occupy a vast area of the country.But they are managed for the benefit of a tiny number of iniduals. And the local wildle is destroyed.AMONG the names Scottish people gave to their newborn babies in  were Lucer, Awesome and Adora-belle.I hope Lucer doesn’t feel victimised in what is primarily a Christian country. And I hope Awesome doesn’t end up sleeping rough in Sauchiehall Street with wee seeping out of his trousers.That would be an ironically cruel fate.But it’s good to see that the most popular name in Scotland for boys was Jack. As in the Union Jack.A BUNCH of nutters are off to Antarctica.The Flat Earth Society is planning a trip to the South Pole to prove once and for all that the earth is indeed the shape of a tea tray. Not a globe at all.It thinks there’s a big ice wall at the edge of Antarctica and it’s impossible to get over.Some of them think that actually the world – and all the stars and planets – are enclosed in a giant dome. A bit like The Truman Show, then.“Why does the moon give out its own light,” one of them asked. .I don’t get these people. Everyone knows the world is triangular, with us at the top, followed by all the good, hard-working protestant countries.That was Zain Osman’s excuse to the court. Well, fair enough. Quite often I’m disgusted at the immorality in modern Britain.And when that happens I immediately shove my hands down the trousers of the first bloke I see and start tugging on his old fella. Natural reaction, isn’t it Mr Osman arrived here illegally. But he was granted asylum. Shouldn’t he be sent back to tend his flock in the vibrant, go-ahead state of Sudan Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: secret civil servant remain bureaucrats undermine brexit
story: Before joining the service I had believed, naively, that these values would be upheld unconditionally. I quickly came to learn that, in relation to Brexit, nothing could be further from the truth.Unfortunately, I must remain anonymous for fear of the backlash I would receive at my place of work.However, I can reveal I am a senior policy professional within the service and work closely with a number of government departments.There are a number of extremely dangerous myths regarding civil servants that I must dispel because of the impact they are having on the Brexit process.MYTH : The civil service is independent. The civil service was founded on the pillars of political neutrality.Civil servants are meant to ensure that their own political persuasions do not affect their work. Crucially, they should accept those from all political leanings and points of view.It has become clear to me that the vast majority of civil servants support Remain.From my observations I would estimate this number to be well over  per cent.This is worrying in itself and far from representative of the  per cent of the people who voted for Brexit.Most horrying, however, is the sheer disdain and utter contempt that my colleagues display towards people who voted to Leave.I have lost count of the number of insulting and derogatory terms that are used in my own department and where to refer to the .million people who voted for Brexit: “Racist”, “stupid”, “uneducated”.Anti-Brexit jokes and snide remarks are dropped casually into everyday office con-versations. I live in fear that my colleagues will discover through a slip of my tongue that I am a Brexiteer.Were this to happen, I believe that most would refuse to talk to me again and I might even lose my job.This entire culture creates a thickening cloud of negativity towards Brexit that shades all areas of the civil service. I have witnessed first-hand civil servants doing everything within their power, subtly and under the surface, to frustrate Brexit and talk it down at every opportunity.This can only seriously undermine our efforts to be in the strongest position possible on leaving the EU.MYTH : Civil servants are experts in their field.One would like to think the iniduals making decisions that affect our entire nation would have some level of skill or experience.If only that were true.For example, I know of one stand-alone “expert” policy team leading our preparations for Brexit.You can imagine my disbelief when I discovered none of its members had worked on anything remotely related to the EU before. In fact, I have discovered over time that the vast majority of “experts” within the service have no expertise whatsoever.In many cases the “portfolio” you take on when you join the service is dictated by the one held by your predecessor.As a result, you have new civil servants inheriting politically sensitive and highly important work without the faintest clue about what they are dealing with.Civil servants who are seriously underperforming will usually have a new job title and position created for them somewhere  in the organisation instead of being sacked or performance-managed — they become someone ’s problem then.Given the influence that civil servants are exerting over the Brexit process, this is truly concerning.MYTH : The civil service does not engage in scaremongering.I had hoped that civil servants, even in times of crisis, would be able to remain calm and level-headed in pursuit of ensuring the best outcomes for our country.And yet it is not uncommon for me to receive emails from colleagues promoting Brexit scare stories that are nothing more than lies and speculation. Recently, things have become so panicked that ious “Brexit contingency” plans have been set up throughout the organisation. This is to prepare for the “national public transport breakdown”, “surge in criminality” and “widespread public unrest” that is going to follow after we leave.These plans also involve collecting the personal details of certain civil servants to put in place a -hour, on-call rota for the “emergency” that is looming. This scare-mongering, created and whipped up by civil servants, is having a marked impact on the confidence and well-being of ordinary citizens.For example, one acquain-tance of mine is so terried by the speculative threats put out by the service they have started to stockpile large quantities of their medication. This needs to stop.MYTH : Ministers are in charge.When I was outside the civil service looking in, I always believed civil servants were there simply to advise their ministers, who, as elected representatives of the people, would make the ultimate decision. However, I have come to realise that ministers are often mere puppets, with civil servants pulling ferociously at their strings.The level of bureaucracy is unimaginable.In my experience parlia-mentary briefings go through — at a minimum — five stages of internal clearance, with crucial information being amended or deleted at every stage on the whim of that inidual civil servant.The power and competence of our ministers is, I’m afraid, a facade.They are nothing more than a megaphone for the views of biased civil servants who lurk behind them in the shadows.I am a supporter of the Leave campaign.To go against the will of the people expressed in the  referendum would be the ultimate act of betrayal.The Government MUST allow us to take back control by leaving the EU on World Trade Organisation terms. If the people are betrayed, I may have no choice but to resign.Honesty, impartiality, integrity and objectivity. We will soon discover, once and for all, whether our politicians embody these values.©The Sunday Times News Licensing Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: tories giving power marxist corbyn
story: Remainers threatening to bring down their own Government to avoid No Deal next week. Leavers are doing the same to avoid delaying or cancelling Brexit.In the crossfire stands Theresa May who — for all her faults — insists she is determined to do right by the people, by our democracy and by the .million majority who voted Leave.The PM has made many errors. But, against mountainous odds and a Remainer-dominated Parliament and civil service, she has at least followed Brexit’s inescapable logic: that it must mean exiting the EU’s main institutions, the single market and customs union.The Sun will not pretend her deal is great. It is just the only one available. It gets Brexit done, as promised. And it does have merit for Leavers, whatever Tory backbenchers protest. Defeat it again and the Government could fall in a no-confidence vote.We do not believe the Tories will win an electionpanicked Remain MPs have halted Brexit, especially with Mrs May in office. They will be punished by Leavers they have failed and Remainers who have already jumped ship.Corbyn is one of Britain’s most reviled politicians, in a crowded field. But his party — cheerleaders for the same debunked ideology now starving Venezuelans to death — could win by default Tory voters don’t turn out.The consequences for our jobs and economy would make a No Deal Brexit look like a picnic. Tory MPs must wake up. This is not a parlour game. An election has never looked closer. Handing power to ­Corbyn will define your careers.But Labour moderates should wake up too before they oppose the deal again.They’ll be left campaigning to put an anti-Semitic Marxist extremist and terrorist sympathiser in Downing Street.CONSIDER the rancid dishonesty of ­Labour’s Brexit position.They claim to be aghast at our national crisis. Except they could resolve it instantly by backing Mrs May’s deal.Why not  They agree with almost every word, except that it does not lock us into a permanent, restrictive customs union. Oh, and it’s a “Tory Brexit”, that meaningless phrase designed to maintain the pretence that there’s dference between their positions.Labour’s sole motive is political gain. The same reason they farcically back leaving and remaining. And why they are for and against a second referendum.They don’t want this crisis to end, nor an orderly Brexit. They relish chaos. It is their best chance to seize power.Only a mug would believe Corbyn, McDonnell or the snakelike Keir Starmer have Britain’s interests at heart.Their priority is not our country. It is imposing socialism.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: theresa may resignation pressure brexit speech
story: Amid uproar in Westminster, backbenchers Anne Marie Trevelyan and Tracey Crouch were among a “large number” who told whips she “had to go”.Ex-Minister Guto Bebb labelled the speech an “utter failure of judgement”.A Whitehall official separately compared the Mrs May’s attack on warring MPs over the Brexit deadlock her ‘Ratner’s moment’ - while sources claimed Chief Whip Julian Smith was openly describing the address as “appalling”.Steve Double, MP, told The Sun he was aware of a number of colleagues who had told the PM to her face thatthey’d only now vote for her dealshe committed to resigning.A number of the  Tory rebels who backed the PM’s deal last week now warned they may ‘switch’ back to opposing it again – including Ben Bradley and Maria Caulfield.The  met the PM just before she made her speech on Wednesday night.One MP said: “The point was made by several people thatshe wanted to get her deal through she would have to say ‘I’m leaving on such and such a date.”Nigel Evans – secretary of the influential Tory  Committee – admitted the PM would have to gothe UK signed up to an extension that forced the UK to hold European Elections.One Tory told The Sun: “There is utter fury at what happened last night.“The idea that the PM could hold drinks with  of us who backed her deal – then cross the road and say that ” Another said: “Patience in the PM has snapped. The speech was the final straw.”The fury came as the PM’s Downing Street address on Wednesday sparked another bitter row with Speaker John Bercow. The Speaker intervened in the Commons to tell MPs they were not “traitors.Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt defended the PM by saying she was under “extraordinary pressure”. But doorstepped on a trip to Essex, Home Secretary Sajid Javid refused to back Mrs May’s blast.Former Labour Minister Caroline Flint yesterday insisted she would still support the PM in a ‘Meaningful Vote ’ and called her deal the best “compromise” available.But leading Labour MP Lisa Nandy warned the PM she had thrown away any chance of winning over any more Labour backbenchers to her cause.Downing Street needs at least  Labour MPs to back the PM’s deal next week to stand any chance of passing it through the Commons.Ms Nandy said: “There is absolutely no chance she is going to win over MPs in sufficient numbers after that statement.”And Labour backbencher Wes Streeting said Mrs May could have blood on her hands. He stormed: “Theresa May knows that MPs across the House are subjected to death threats – some very credible.“Her speech was incendiary and irresponsible.“If any harm comes to us, she will have to accept her share of responsibility.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: tory mp admits fiddling his office expenses and could face a year behind bars
story: Christopher Davies admitted to two charges involving falsying invoices related to his Parliamentary expenses claims for furniture and pictures for his office.District Judge John Zani said that although there was no financial gain for his actions he admitted two very serious offences which were absolutely intended to deceive.He now faces being booted out of Parliament as a recall petition is automatically triggered in relation to expenses.His own voters in Brecon and Radnorshire will have their say on whether they want to trigger a by-election in the area and vote in a new MP.But the Tories today refused to say whether or not hed be kicked out of the party after his criminal conviction.The first charge he admitted to was providing  or misleading information for allowances claims.He said that in March  he made a claim under the MPs allowances scheme and provided an invoice that he knew to be  or misleading.The second charge was attempting to provide  or misleading information for an allowance claim using an invoice that he knew to be  or misleading in April .The former Parliamentary Private Secretary appeared at Westminster Magistrates Court earlier today and could face a year behind bars.The judge said he did not consider the sentencing power of Westminster Magistrates Court to be sufficient and sent the case to crown court.Thomas Forster QC, defending, told the court Davies accepts his responsibility and expresses his sincere and unreserved apology for what he has done.Mr Forster said of the -year-old: A disastrous accounting episode, as far as he is concerned.Speaker Bercow was informed of his guilty plea before he made it.The police were handed a dossier of evidence last year relating to the MP.Mr Davies was questioned twice about his expenses over a claim back in .The MP claimed he made an honest mistake with the claims.Mr Davies was accused of manually creating two invoices for £ and £ rather than submitting the full £ claim for the pictures.He had previously said that he repaid the £ sum, which was charged to a start-up fund for new MPs to set up offices.Today Labours party chair Ian Lavery said: Trust in politics and politicians is essential to our democracy. Chris Davies cannot remain a Tory MP after admitting to this offence.A Conservative spokesperson said today: “As this is an ongoing legal matter, we will not be commenting.”It is unclear whether the MP will have the whip suspended or will face any action from the party at this stage.CHRISTOPHER Davies could be booted out of his seathes given a sentence for his expenses crime.After pleading guilty today he will be told of his fate and whether he faces any jail time for it.An MP cant be automatically booted unless they get a sentence of a year or more.If its less than a year but he still gets sentenced then a recall petition is triggered.As his charge is related to expenses than a recall petition is called automatically.If enough of his own constituents sign it, then a by-election is called.Mr Davies could stand again buthes sentenced then its likely his party will boot him out as their candidate and put up someone  instead for the Conservatives.He currently is the MP for Brecon and Radnorshire after winning the seat in .His majority is more than ,, which is still possible to be overturned in a by-election.The constituency was previously held by the Liberal Democrats for  years, but the seat did vote  per cent to leave the EU back in .If he resigns from the Commons before MPs vote on the Brexit deal then Mrs May could be one vital vote down.The Tory has backed her deal in the last two crunch clashes.The PM is set to bring it back next week just days before Britain is due to leave the bloc.

title: brussels bosses demand 6m from uk claiming our weather forecasters broke contract by being lazy
story: The European Commission is demanding the UK£million granted to the weather watchers to help study climate change.In an astonishing move, the Commission claims the Met needs to hand back the cash because of inadequate timekeeping procedures.The cross-EU programmes date from  to  and the cash demand - at the height of Brexit tensions - follows a Brussels audit of Met Office work.Theresa May is already poised to hand Brussels £billion -she can get her Brexit deal through the Commons.Business Secretary Greg Clark – one of the most Europhile ministers in Theresa May’s Cabinet – has vowed to mount a legal challenge over the row.One person briefed on the case told The Sun: “Even Greg thinks there are is an argument to take them on over this.He believes we should be able to overturn the decision.“It comes from a Commission’s audit of the Met Office – which is ironic when the EU’s accounts weren’t signed off for years.”Neither the Department for Business nor the Met Office would comment.

title: parcel bomb irish post depot london glasgow
story: Garda called Army bomb disposal experts to the postal sorting office in Limerick this morning after the suspicious package was discovered.Around  staff were evacuated and postal services in Limerick were suspended.The Defence Forces later confirmed a viable improvised explosive device had been found contained in a plastic envelope.Irish Justice Minister Charlie Flanagan said a stamp on the package found in the An Post depot on Dock Road in the city was similar to those used on letter bombs sent to the UK earlier this month.Flanagan added: This is a despicable act.The sending of incendiary devices like this is totally unacceptable. I hope the people responsible are brought to justice.The building was evacuated during the security alert.A spokesman for the Defence Forces said: A viable improvised explosive device contained in a plastic envelope was identied and made safe. The device was then handed over to An Garda Siochana for further investigation.A group calling itself the IRA has claimed responsibility for parcel bombs sent to major transport hubs in London and the University of Glasgow.The organisation, known to police as the New IRA, claimed one parcel addressed to a British Army recruitment officer may not have been discovered yet.The group said it posted five devices to addresses in Britain, however only four had been discovered at the time the claim of responsibility was sent to a Belfast newsroom.It is formed of dissident Republicans who reject Northern Ireland’s peace process, which saw paramilitary groups decommission weapons in order to end The Troubles.The IRA was disbanded after the decommissioning and has been inactive for several years but several groups have sprung up under the name.In , the New IRA sent failed devices to Army career offices in England and carried out a car bombing in Londonderry.The New IRA was also behind an attack in  when a prison officer died after a bomb exploded under his van in Belfast.MI’s threat warning of a ­Republican terror attack remains at moderate but police in Northern Ireland and Ireland fear ato a hard border after Brexit, complete with customs and other checks, could be a target for militant groups.Mr Flanagan said the item found in Limerick could be the fth.We have reason to believe this could be the case, he said.The packages that arrived at Waterloo railway station and offices at Heathrow and London City airports on March  and  were posted with Irish stamps and had Dublin as theaddress, prompting Irish police to join the investigation.The stamps appeared to be those issued by the Irish postal service for Valentines Day , featuring a heart mot and the words Love Eire N.The senders addresses were given as Dublin, with two having added coach operator Bus Eireann.Police Scotland said a controlled explosion was carried out as a precaution on a suspicious package found in the mailroom at Glasgow University, after several buildings had been evacuated.All packages were A-sized white postal bags containing yellow Jfy bags and appeared capable of igniting a small fire when opened.No-one was injured in any of the incidents in Britain.A Garda spokesman said: This parcel appears to be identical to parcels - pending closer forensic and ballistic examination - discovered earlier this month in London and Glasgow.An Garda Siochana continue to liaise with the UK authorities in relation to these investigations.Irish premier Leo Varadkar condemned the actions of those involved.Speaking in Brussels, he said: First of all I condemn the actions of whoever did this without reservation, no matter what is happening in politics at the moment, its no justication for violence and certainly no justication for potentially exposing civilians to injury or potentially death.The Minister for Justice was in touch with me this morning to inform me of what they know so far, and they did know there were five letter bombs sent a few weeks ago and the fth one has turned up at a postal centre in Limerick so we believe its one of the same batch and this is the fth one now.

title: meghan markle prince harry delay house move
story: The couple hoped to move in to Frogmore Cottage this week but workmen are well behind.They have now targeted next month — just a week or so before baby Sussex is born.A royal source said: “It’s been all hands to the pump. The builders have worked all week whatever the weather. But they keep making changes, particularly on the layout.“The word is they’ve been quite demanding, which is understandable as what homeowner doesn’t want their house to be perfect ”Harry, , and Meghan, , have knocked down many of the interior walls to create five huge bedrooms and en-suite bathrooms.They have views over Windsor Great Park and the gardens of Frogmore House, where they held their wedding party last year.A huge kitchen diner has been created.The couple have also ordered alcove bookcases to go next to new fireplaces and vanity units.Last week builders on cranes put in chimney liners for log burners.The source said: “Given the scale of the project, a three or four-week delay isn’t too bad. title: baby life saved doctor sniffed earwax
story: Harini Rasalingam was rushed to hospital at just six days old following dramatic weight loss.Medics could find nothing wrong so transferred her to the Evelina London Children’s Hospital, which runs a ­specialist unit for rare illnesses.Paediatrician Helen Mundy swabbed her ear, and one snf confirmed her suspicions — maple syrup urine disease.The rare but deadly condition occurs when the body cannot break down ­protein in food. I cried when I saw her.”She was then transferred to Evelina, where Dr Mundy also noticed Harini was irritable and making unusual arching movements, other tell-tale signs.Dr Mundy, a consultant in paediatric inherited metabolic medicine, said: “Maple syrup urine disease is a very serious condition and left untreated it can be fatal.“Thankfully, we knew that sweet smelling ear wax is a sign of it.”Harini spent three weeks in intensive care, where a dialysis-like treatment lowered her amino acid levels.Two years on, she is a happy, healthy toddler with a special low-protein diet which bans meat, fish and cheese.Preminy, who runs a petrol station with her partner Rasalingam Kanakan, , said: “If she hadn’t been diagnosed in time, she wouldn’t be here now. title: mh370 malaysian airlines co pilot use mobile aircraft vanished
story: The doomed jet disappeared on March , , en route from Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, to Beijing with  people on board.A police investigation has now emerged claiming a Malaysian telecom tower detected a mobile number registered to Fariq Abdul Hamid a few minutes before the plane dropped off the radar.There have been a whole host of theories speculating what happened to the flight.The latest alleged evidence about the mobile would appear to support the idea the plane was crashed into the sea in a mass murder-suicide, former Easyjet chief pilot Mike Keane has suggested.According to the theory, the captain may have told Fariq to go to the cabin before locking himself in the cockpit.Fariq though would have had his mobile after takeoff, so the theory goes, and tried to make an emergency call when he realised what was happening and the plane was being depressurised.Keane said: “The first officer would have been skilled in responding to depressurisation due to regular training.“If Fariq had his mobile phone with him, he would have grabbed an oxygen bottle before taking his phone off flight mode or switching it on.”Authorities in Malaysia had previously dismissed reports of the phone detection, which were first made in April , according to The Australian.The confidential police report which detailed the phone has been leaked online and backed up the view the authorities knew the phone had been detected.Mystery has surrounded the disappearance of the plane, which has never been found.Canadian aviation expert Larry Vance has said previously he was “certain” either captain Zaharie Ahmad Shah or co-pilot Fariq Abdul Hamid took over the plane in what he said was “criminal event” and “made it disappear forever”.Passengers included Chinese calligraphers, a couple on their way home to their young sons after a long-delayed honeymoon and a construction worker who hadnt been home in a year.But at .am on March , , Malaysia Airlines lost contact with MH close to Phuket island in the Strait of Malacca.Before that, Malaysian authorities believe the last words heard from the plane, from either the pilot or co-pilot, was Good night Malaysian three seven zero.Satellite pings from the aircraft suggest it continued flying for around seven hours when the fuel would have run out.Experts have calculated the most likely crash site around , miles west of Perth, Australia.But a huge search of the seabed failed to find any wreckage - and there are a number of alternative theories as to its fate. Vance, who previously worked for the Transportation Safety Board of Canada, told CBC News: “It’s not an accident. This was planned and conducted, carried out by one inidual who had control of the aeroplane via his job to have control of the plane.”He claimed that the pilot or co-pilot made the decision “to take it to a remote part of the ocean and make it disappear forever”.Vance spent  months doing research for his book MH Mystery Solved, but he was not part of the official investigation by the Australian Transport Safety Bureau.Some feared Russian president Vladimir Putin was involved in the hijacking of MH. US Science writer Jeff Wise claimed Putin spoofed the planes navigation data so it could fly unnoticed into Baikonur Cosmodrome so he could hurt the West.French ex-airline director Marc Dugain accused the US military of shooting down the plane because they feared it had been hijacked. A book called Flight MH – The Mystery also suggested that it had been shot down accidentally by US-Thai joint jet fighters during a military exercise and covered it up.Malaysia police chief Tan Sri Khalid Abu Bakar suggested the disappearance could have been the result of a suicide. He claimed someone on board could have taken out a large le insurance package before getting on the plane, so they could treat their family or pay back the money they owed.Historian and writer Norman Davies suggested MH could have been remotely hacked and flown to a secret location as a result of sensitive material being carried aboard the jet.

title: theresa may brexit deal must offer job face general election
story: Over the next three weeks, all sorts of choices will race into view. But this country won’t know where things are going to end up until April .On Wednesday, No Deal ­suddenly seemed a likely option again. The EU were saying they would only grant Theresa May’s request for an extensionher Brexit deal passed before March , something that is highly unlikely.I am told that at the No Deal ministers’ meeting on Wednesday night, “the mood was totally dferent to previous meetings, as people thought it might actually happen”.It was agreed that a small group of ministers — Theresa May’s effective deputy David Lidington, Home Secretary Sajid Javid, Health ­Secretary Matt Hancock, Environment Secretary Michael Gove and Northern Ireland Secretary Karen Bradley — would meet again on Friday morning to take the preparations to the next stage.But on Friday morning that meeting was cancelled.Why  Because after the EU agreed to halt the UK’s ­departure until at least April , No Deal is once again highly unlikely.This delay meansMay’s deal fails again, ­Parliament will have enough time to step in and take ­control of the process.The three options now are: May’s deal passes, a softer Brexit is agreed in the next few weeks, or there is a much longer extension to allow a General Election to be held, which could mean no Brexit at all. At the moment, the Brexit deal isn’t going to pass.Getting it through was always going to be hard, but the errors Mrs May made this week have made it even more ­dficult.As one Secretary of State puts it: “She would have been much better off spending three days in bed.”Her speech on Wednesday night, criticising MPs, was also ill-judged, given that they are who she needs to win over.It was particularly mistaken given May had turned down an invitation to address her own MPs that evening.One normally mild-mannered backbencher tells me: “It was offensive to us. You decline to come and talk to us — then insult us.”The Government’s domino strategy for winning the vote required getting the DUP to come on board.There is only one way to change this dynamic — for May to offer to goher deal passes.This would instantly change the debate. In the past few days, one Tory MP who wants No Deal and another who wants a second referendum told me they would vote for a ­withdrawal agreementthey had a guarantee she would go.“An increasing number of people are saying their vote is contingent on her going,” says a senior backbencher.As one Cabinet minister admits: “Even that may not be enough.” But without it, there’s no chance of the deal passing next week.James Forsyth is political editor of The Spectator.AMID all this uncertainty, one thing is looking increasingly clear: Britain will have a new Prime Minister soon.Opinion has turned against Theresa May ­following her ill-judged speech on Wednesday.“She has managed to offend everybody,” one previously loyal minister tells me.And one Secretary of State fumes: “She’s alienated Parliament, the Cabinet and the EU.”There are no shortage of leadership candidates sounding people out.Jeremy Hunt, the Foreign Secretary, has the support of more ­Cabinet ministers than anybody . He is seen as a safe pair of hands and as having the ­emotional intelligence to hold the party together.Sajid Javid was the frontrunner. But as always happens in Tory leadership contests, that has put a target on his back. He has had a dficult few weeks and is losing support.Cabinet ministers are convinced that Andrea Leadsom is running. They point out how, at Cabinet this week, she spoke in a string of highly quotable lines about Leave voters being let down.Liz Truss, the Chief Secretary to the Treasury, is also expected to go for it. But many think she is more interested in framing the debate and pushing her pro-growth agenda than anything .Michael Gove is being urged to stand, with Mel Stride, the well-connected Treasury minister, at the forefront of efforts to persuade Gove to run.Matt Hancock is another being encouraged to enter the race. He is the new toast of the party donor classes, who think he offers competence. One MP describes him as “a better version of Jeremy Hunt”.On the backbenches, Dominic Raab and Boris Johnson are competing to be the Brexiteer ­candidate. Raab’s campaign is better organised – he has ten MPs gathering support for him.But Johnson has the proven electoral record and greater experience. One thing to remember, though. Tory leadership races are like the Grand National: Messy, unpredictable and the favourite rarely wins. THE absurdity of Labour’s Brexit position is that it accepts the withdrawal agreement.What it takes issue with is the political ­declaration, which isn’t legally binding.Voting through the Brexit deal would not stop Labour from getting to any of the softer Brexit ­outcomes that it has been proposing in recent months.You could negotiate almost any kind of Brexit from the withdrawal agreement.But Jeremy Corbyn doesn’t want to vote for it because he doesn’t want to vote for a “Tory Brexit”.It would bring the withdrawal agreement, ­without the political declaration, to the Commons and dare Labour to vote it down.If Labour blinked and the withdrawal agreement passed, we would then be out of the EU and into the transition ­period.The EU would also be satisfied and consider us to have ratied the agreement.If Labour voted down the withdrawal agreement, then it would be clear what their motives were.IF there is no chance of the Brexit deal ­passing unless Theresa May promises to go, who can tell her that This is what ministers have been discussing with each other in the past  hours. They think her No aides won’t, so somebody  needs to.The obvious candidate is Sir ­Graham Brady, chairman of the  Committee of Tory MPs. Brady is discreet and respected. But it is now time for him to put on his grey suit and carry this message to May.May promising to go so long as the withdrawal ­agreement is passed would show that it really isn’t all about her.And history would view her in a much more sympathetic light.ONE reason why the UK might end up leaving the EU by April  is the Labour leadership don’t want the European elections to take place any more than ­Theresa May does.They know parties in favour of a second referendum would attack Labour for its equivocation on this point.Jeremy Corbyn, who walked out of a meeting this week because Chuka Umunna had been invited, wouldn’t want to give the breakaway ­Independent Group such a perfect launch pad.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: NewsopinionCross-party negotiations may be the only way to achieve Brexit with unity, pride and purposeGloria De Piero, Labour MP for Ashfield, explains why Common Market . compromise is better than a No Deal or a second referendumShareCommentsByGloria De Piero:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsopinionGloria De Piero says that short of Labours Brexit plan, working cross-party is undoubtedly the best way to solve the issue "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAs a Labour MP in a seat which overwhelmingly voted Leave, I have experienced more than most the depth, breadth and strength of feeling emanating from the UK’s decision to leave the European Union. I campaigned to Remain, but I have been clear from day one that we must all accept the result of the Referendum and work towards the best possible Brexit for the UK. If Labour’s alternative plan for a close economic relationship can’t get a parliamentary majority, then Common Market . is a Brexit compromise which might just get us out of this dficult period and out the other side with unity, pride and purpose. We would leave the political institutions of the EU, taking control of our laws, our farming and our fisheries but keep close economic ties to our neighbours. It would avoid a catastrophic No Deal — which would be a disaster for businesses in places like Ashfield. It would avoid a isive second referendum.    While not perfect, it is a Brexit that can deliver on the result of the referendum whilst protecting jobs, enhancing our control over EU migration and restoring sovereignty to the UK. I hear time and again from leave voters in my constituency that they voted leave because they want the laws that govern this land to be made in this land. They want us to be able to trade freely with Europe, without Europe dictating how we run our country. Common Market . would restore the UK-EU relationship to the type of popular economic partnership we had with Europe in the s. We would leave the EU and its political institutions to join the European Free Trade Association, then access the single market through the European Economic Area. The EEA Agreement allows safeguards on migration, so non-EU EEA countries can pause freedom of movementit is causing ‘serious economic or societal dficulties’. Time is running out to secure a Brexit deal that works for places like Ashfield. Common Market . represents the fastest route to Brexit we could agree a rewritten Political Declarationand leave on schedule. This week Jeremy Corbyn again met with Labour and Conservative MPs who are championing Common Market .. If Labour’s plan for Brexit can’t get through the House of Commons, it’s absolutely right that our politicians are working cross-party to secure a sensible Brexit.

title: abandoned baby rat infested canal
story: NewsAbandoned as baby on rat-infested canal - I could only be happy when I found out whyEXCLUSIVE: As a newborn, Richard Gallear was discovered wrapped in newspaper by a postman - and a dark childhood awaited himShareCommentsByJulie McCaffrey:,  MAR NewsThe incredible story of canal rescue baby Richard Gallear has been turned into a book"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailSitting nervously in a stuffy office as he opened his adoption file for the first time in , Richard Gallear was handed a newspaper cutting yellowed with age. Under the headline “Baby left on canal bank”, it told of a premature boy, barely two hours old, found abandoned on a freezing November night, wrapped only in two sheets of newspaper. The dark truth of his birth left him devastated. Richard, , says: “I was so horried I felt numb. I tried to read on, but couldn’t take it in because my eyes filled and blurred my vision. “It was a terrible story to read about any baby, and realising that baby was me felt overwhelming. “Knowing I came into the world like that, unwanted from the moment I arrived and left to die in minus two degree temperatures, made me sob for three hours afterwards.” It was a miracle Richard survived the rat-infested canal bank in Birmingham’s Gas Street Basin. But his headline-grabbing birth was the start of a childhood so tumultuous he recalls his years in a children’s home as his happiest. Being adopted at the age of four should have been the moment Richard felt the love of a family and a chance to find security and happiness. Instead, he endured merciless beatings from his sadistic adoptive father.  Since that traumatic day in the adoption office, Richard has traced blood relatives and information about the man who saved him from the canal. Gradually, with painstaking research, he has pieced together the story of his le and family and felt able to move on. Richard says: “I’ve spent decades wondering about my birth parents. Maybe to ease the painful knowledge that they had given me up, I wrapped thoughts of them in romantic stories. “Maybe my blood mum and dad were lovers too young, or too poor, to bring me up as well as they’d hoped  “Maybe they wept as they handed me over to a children’s home  I always hoped that one Mother’s Day I’d turn up at my mum’s home with chocolates and flowers, and she would throw her arms around her long-lost son.” Reading his adoption file shattered all his illusions. Richard read that his birth mum Lucy Cunningham was  when she had him.    Lucy had abandoned her three children and husband to be with his birth father Harold Wrenn. She had a daughter with him before Richard’s birth, and two other children after him. Harold, a gang leader in league with the Kray twins, was in prison when Richard was born and never knew he existed. Lucy had always refused to see any reminders of the baby she gave birth to on the freezing canal bank. Richard says: “According to my file, Lucy had been offered pictures of me throughout my le and declined to see them. As I read all this information, all the self-esteem I’d ever built up vanished. I was left feeling utterly inadequate, isolated and inferior. “My adoptive father always said nobody had wanted me, and I started to feel that was true.” Hitting rock bottom that day he saw his file in the Birmingham Children’s Services offices gave Richard, from the West Midlands, no other option but to rise up. Realising how lucky he was to be alive, his first vow was to find and thank the man who had rescued him from the canal bank. At around pm on November , , postman Joseph Lester had just finished his sht at Birmingham’s sorting office and was walking home through freezing fog. It was a familiar route and Joseph was used to hearing the lapping water and muffled sounds of the city as he walked.  That night he was alerted to a faint whimper. He beamed his torch over the water and strained his eyes in the darkness until he spotted something pale. He stooped to find what looked like a parcel wrapped in newspaper, only two or three inches from the water’s edge. As he peeled back the paper, Joseph saw a newborn baby who was white and cold. He tucked the baby inside his coat and walked to the nearest phone box to call . Richard says: “I found this out from newspaper cuttings. Because that evening, Joseph ed home to his we and kids, and this kind, heroic man was so humble he did not tell his family he had just saved a le. “When I tried to find him, I was sad to find a record of his death. But I was so happy to meet Joseph’s sons, John and Keith, who said their dad often helped people without telling a soul.” Richard’s quest to find out more about his early le led him to trace some half siblings, who are now in regular contact and share stories of their childhood with empathy. Richard says: “It was a strange feeling to meet siblings – asI felt every emotion I had ever known rolled into one. “They gave me the first photos I’d ever seen of my birth mother and father. “With my half sister Patricia, I felt a genuine connection between us and an outpouring of love that I will cherish for the rest of my le.”  Patricia had attended their mother’s cremation and visiting the cemetery last September finally gave Richard the closure he craved and helped him look back on his le with new appreciation. He says: “My birth mother died in . Cemetery staff were good enough to open the book of remembrance from the day her ashes were interred, and I saw the names of her six other kids there, but not mine. “That felt like another blow, asI had been purged from her existence. Why had she singled me out  Why was I so bad  “When I was taken to the spot where her ashes were interred, I laid a white roses and tied a photograph of myself to them. “I said, ‘You didn’t want a picture of me when I was alive. But you have one of me now’. “Lucy kept all knowledge of her pregnancy and me from everyone, including my father, my brothers and sisters. I was a secret she took to her grave. “That’s why I had to close the circle, in the way I did in the hope I could move my le forward. “When I drove home that night I felt lighter. I’d done everything I could to find out about my birth family and when my front door closed, I felt I’d laid my past to rest.” Finding the truth about his birth hurt Richard so deeply because le with his adoptive parents had been far from happy. His first four years were spent in Field House children’s home in Clent, Stourbridge, Worcs, and he has only fond memories of his time there.  But the moment Richard met his adoptive parents he felt uneasy with Arnold Gallear, who would not look him in the eye. His instincts were right. Although Arnold’s we Pearl was gentle, patient and caring, Arnold was violent towards Richard, putting him in hospital more than once. The first time Richard suffered at Arnold’s fists, and feet, was just minutes after leaving the children’s home. Furious when Richard was sick in the back of his van, Arnold slammed on the brakes, hauled him out on to the road and laid into him with kicks and punches. Richard says: “No adult had ever hurt me in any way before, let alone hit me. I had a horrible feeling that this was what le would be like from now on. And it was.” On the outside, Arnold was a well-off insurance executive, regular church-goer and loyal member of The Salvation Army. But behind closed doors he ruthlessly controlled we Pearl and constantly verbally and physically attacked Richard.  He says: “He was a sadistic tyrant. But every time social services visited our home to check how I was, they interviewed me in front of Pearl and Arnold and I couldn’t tell the truth. “Teachers and doctors noticed my cuts, bruises, black eyes and broken bones. But no one intervened.” Richard escaped his unhappy home le at , when he ran away to work in the hotel and catering industry, where he could live on-site. Over the years he built up businesses of his own, but never felt he could trust anyone enough to have a lasting, loving relationship. He says: “I felt that loving someone would mean they’d vanish from my le. “First my house mother at the children’s home, who I loved but had to leave behind when I was adopted. And my adoptive mother, who suffered greatly because of Arnold’s violence against me.  “She could never show me affection when he was around, so lived on her nerves and it wore her down. “When I left to take jobs in hotels, I didn’t tell Pearl where I was going or keep in touch because I didn’t want Arnold to know where I was for both our sakes. “That has haunted me all my le and I missed her dreadfully. “So although I never settled down to have a family, I’m blessed with a circle of friends who are so loyal and close I call them my chosen family.” Writing his story in a new book, The Forgotten Child, gave Richard time to reflect on his le. Now, most of all, he feels lucky. He says: “I was incredibly lucky to be found that night on the canal, and also lucky not to have inherited any character traits from my birth parents or adoptive father. “I’m fortunate to have built up businesses to make sure I live comfortably. And I’m lucky I’m still here, despite the way I was born and some health bumps along the way.  “It makes me feel sure someone up there is looking out for me. Researching my le has made me feel, after a letime of self-blame and insecurity, that the bad things that happened were not my fault. “It’s helped me fully move on from the sad aspects of my le, and now I feel I’ve found peace and can finally be happy.”The Forgotten Child, by Richard Gallear, published by HarperCollins, on  March at £.

story: NewsDad blinded man in one eye after hitting him with pint glass on dancefloorThe victim Daniel Robers underwent seven hours of surgery after he was hit by Nathan Stevens - but they were unable to save the visionShareByChris SlaterTfany Lo:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsVictim Daniel Roberts, , was left blind in one eye after being glassed in Hula bar by Nathan Stevens "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA father has blinded a man in one eye after glassing him in a dancefloor tussle at a bar in Machester. Nathan Stevens, , of Edgeley, Stockport, lashed out with aposexcessive self defenceapos when challenging a punter at Hula Bar in West Didsbury, last year, a court heard. The assault started when Stevens had apostaken exceptionapos to something the victim Daniel Roberts had said to one of his female friends on the dancefloor at the venue last April, and aposwords were exchangedapos between, the judge was told. Mr Roberts initially pushed him but Stevens argued in court that he was grabbed by the throat. But Stevens responded by swinging a punch with a beer glass, which ended up sending glasses in the face of -year-old Mr Roberts.  Mr Roberts was rushed to hospital where doctors performed a seven-hour operation in bid to save the sight of his left eye, but it was unsuccessful. He also sustained a number of deep cuts on his face which now have left him scarred. Prosecutor Maria Brannan said Mr Roberts, who works as an electrician, spent three months off work and now struggled having lost half of his vision. In a statement read in the court, the victimaposs eyeball was luckily saved thanks to a silicon implant which helps it retain in its shape, but he had to put steroid drops into it every day. Mr Roberts said: I am normally a very positive person but I have down days when I wished this had never happened and that I still had the sight in my eye. He was pushed against the wall after the attack and Stevens, who didnapost realise how bad the injury was, left the bar. But Stevens handed himself in to police weeks later after an appeal in the Manchester Evening News.    The Stockport man pleaded guilty to unlawful wounding at an earlier hearing. He stated in a plea that the blow was a case of aposexcessive self defenceapos after he was pushed or grabbed by the victim. Daniel Travers, defending, said the father had been left aposdevastated at the injury he had caused and aposthat was never his intentionapos. He said: He knows how signicant an effect that will have for the rest ofle. This is a very poor reaction and was a very bad decision made whilst in drink. It is an immediate and instinctive reaction and we are talking about a few seconds. He has not picked up the glass to use as a weapon, it was already in his dominant hand and thataposs what has caused this injury. He urged Judge Timothy Clayson to suspend any prison term as court was told Stevens was aposcommittedapos to his family, including his children. However those appeals were ignored and he was jailed for two years and four months at Manchester Crown Court on Thursday afternoon.    Passing sentence, Judge Clayson said: This is a really tragic situation which has resulted in the loss of sight in one eye, an injury that is lelong and grave. This was not pre-meditated, it was a single blow which was issued in response to a push or you being grabbed for a few seconds by the throat. However you were affected by alcohol and itaposs right that you would have likely not have reacted by swinging a punch at your victimyou had been sober. She thinks itaposs fantastic and my son is really proud. My grandson thinks Iaposm the coolest gran ever. title: groom cancels dream las vegas
story: NewsGroom cancels dream Las Vegas stag do after best man runs off with £,Swindon husband-to-be was looking forward to an extravagant Vegas stag with nine pals but then disaster struckShareCommentsByAdam Aspinall:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsBen, centre, with pals Stuart and Phil who will now accompany him on a less glamorous stag "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailGroom Ben Whincup should be living it up in Las Vegas, ­enjoying the stag do he and his pals spent a year planning as the trip of a letime. Instead, he is drowning his sorrows in a pub in hometown Swindon — claiming the best man they trusted to organise things with almost £, called the night before they were due to fly and confessed to spending it all without booking anything. Ben, , said: “I could not believe what I was hearing. “I never even got angry really, it was just shock and disbelief. “You can’t believe someone would do something like that. “So we’ve gone from thinking we’d be at a pool party in Vegas to sat having a beer in Swindon.”    Ben, who ties the knot with fiancee Emma in Royal Wootton Bassett on April , planned the Sin City jaunt with three pals from Swindon St George Rugby League Club, dad Craig, his two brothers-in-law and another family friend. They all handed cash over to the best man. Ben, a rugby coach at Gloucester University who also works as a service engineer, said: “As soon as we had set a date, I told Emma I wanted to go to Vegas for the stag party.  “I’d always dreamed of playing the tables in those iconic casinos and what better time than just before I get married  “We had decided on the flights and the hotel on the strip where we would stay, and he just said he’d take care of it all. “We handed over more than £ each and trusted him to deliver the dream trip. In the weeks running up to the stag, we were all getting excited and there were no signs that anything was wrong.”  Telling of his shock when he got the confession call, Ben said: “I was stunned. I couldn’t believe what he’d done. “It wasn’t just my money, there were others who were going to miss out on a trip of a letime.” To make matters worse, one of the stag members is already in Las Vegas after travelling to Nevada from his home in New Zealand. Police are probing and Ben and his group tried to keep the Vegas dream alive – but flights were too dear.  Ben, whose stag plans had included hitting the Hakkasan party venue, said: “It looks like a weekend in Newcastle rather than Vegas. “There is no use moping about it, I am just trying to make the best of a bad situation and even see the humour in itI can.” Thankfully, Emma’s hen party — a weekend of drinks and games in a Somerset mansion — went without any hitches. Emma, , said: “Ben and his friends were so looking forward to the trip and what happened has been a blow. But they’ll find something  and have a good time.”  Ben added: “At least Emma had a good time and I’m sure we’ll have a blast — just not on the tables in Vegas.” Wiltshire police said: “We can confirm this matter is being investigated. It would be inappropriate to comment further.”
