story: NewsMum who became incontinent after childbirth hid it from husband for YEARSEXCLUSIVE: Kelly-Anne Combes, from Kings Lynn, Norfolk, became completely incontinent following the birth of her daughter which put a strain on her relationshipShareCommentsByBradley Jolly:,  MAR NewsKelly-Anne Combes suffered incontinence after Amelia was born "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum who became incontinent after giving birth to her daughter lived in a constant state of embarrassment and even hid her condition from her husband.Kelly-Anne Combes, , was so humiliated about her severe bladder weakness she desperately kept it a secret from her husband for more than a year.The writer, from Kingaposs Lynn, Norfolk, found she was repeatedly wetting herself in public and social situations, and compared her plight to having to potty train herself. She took spare clothes out with her and frequently had to change into them. Yet she suffered in silence. Speaking exclusively to , Kelly-Anne said: I didnapost tell my husband. I didnapost feel I needed to. I couldnapost face telling my friends either. I just made constant excuses as to why I couldnapost go out or see them. I was just so mortied.    Initially, I only confided in my mum, she was the one person that I felt comfortable with telling as I knew she wouldnapost judge me.  But to begin with, it happened a lot but I thought this was just a normal experience after childbirth.Kelly-Anne, who is a lestyle blogger, gave birth to miracle baby Amelia in June  after experiencing dficulty conceiving.But she was mortied to first feel a trickle weeks after childbirth, which quickly became a heavy leak. My sister bought a trampoline so I decided to give it a go.    It began as a trickle, rather than the heavy leak, but I knew something wasnapost right. Initially I ignored it, sweeping it under the carpet as I couldnapost admit that I would have this issue. I had heard of middle-aged women experiencing bladder weakness but not someone of my age. I found it all very embarrassing, the graduate added. The mother-of-oneaposs social le was quickly ruined and the ordeal put a strain on her relationship with her -year-old husband, who doesnapost want to be named. Kelly-Anne stopped going out, distanced herself from her hubby and mates, and grew more and more anxious.    It took her months before she found the courage to tell her mum and sister, who by this stage had four children of her own. The lestyle writer added: I completely lost my confidence and went into isolation. I stopped socialising because I could never relax. Living in a state of anxiety and embarrassment, I soon stopped leaving the house. My way of managing was to isolate myself and not to go out. Feeling shame and embarrassment was a risk that I was not willing to take. But after more than a year of shirking the issue and cover-ups to her hubby, Kelly-Anne was forced to tell him of her plight during a family holiday in August .  Recalling a poignant day, Kelly-Anne said: I was playing football with my husband and Amelia on a beach and I jumped up, and it happened. I had to tell him because I really needed to go back the apartment to get changed. I said aposthis has been happening for a while nowapos and it was becoming more regular than just every so often. He didnapost really know what to say. I donapost think he could quite understand but neither did I really. The only way I can describe it is experiencing the worries of potty training yet itaposs for yourself and not your child. Kelly-Anne eventually saw a doctor and was referred to a professional. The muscles around the mumaposs bladder had become weakened during pregnancy and after childbirth, which led to the urinary incontience. But a third of women suffer from incontinence in the first three months after childbirth, recent statistics show. It was suggested Kelly-Anne used a pair of shorts with electro muscle stimulation technology to help her recovery. The self-confessed tea addict been using the INNOVO shorts infrequently for around three months now and theyaposve helped her get her le back. The blogger continued: I am doing all those things that bladder weakness stopped me from doing for so long. I am out and about, mingling with other mums and feel like me again. I have regained so much confidence again. It feels amazing to let go of those feelings of embarrassment.  I can kick a football around with my husband and daughter, and use the trampoline. The shorts have strengthen Kelly-Anneaposs pelvic floor. These muscles, which keep the bladder shut, come under great strain in pregnancy and childbirth. Professionals suggest mums and expectant mums do simple exercises to strengthen thew muscles. But Kelly-Anne stressed it is also important not to feel alone. My advice to others would be to not feel alone because there are so many women out there who have been through the same thing. Nobody should feel that they need to suffer in silence and be too embarrassed to seek help like I was. Everybody should value their quality of le and not give up years of their le, like I did.

received a letter saying she did not qualy for mental health support "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA young woman has voiced her horror after being told she was too fat to get professional help for her severe eating disorder. Sammy Halstead, , from Caerphilly, said her condition spiralled out of control before she went for an assessment with a community mental health teamin Cardf. But to her horror she was told that she didnapost meet the criteria for specialist eating disorder support as her body mass index  was not low enough.The psychology student told Wales Live the rejection letter made her think she shouldnapost take on more calories.Sammy has had long-term struggles with food intake and compulsively exercising, as well as self-harming and attempting suicide.    Reaching out for support - before it spiralled out of control - was dficult enough for me, she said. But to then to receive a letter quite simply stating that I was too fat for them to bother helping me made me think I was some kind of fraud. The letter haunts me. I think of it every single time I eat a meal, that my BMI is far too high and how I shouldnapost consume calories. Iaposve read and heard some very invalidating things from professionals, but nothing which had invalidated my struggles surrounding food like this did. Before moving to Cardf, Sammy was deemed eligible for specialist eating disorder services by the Caerphilly CMHT.    I saw my nurse weekly who would offer therapy and support surrounding my issues with food and weight, she said. But as my self-harm began to escalate I was discharged from the eating disorder service in the hope Iaposd get support for the other areas of my mental health. However I barely saw my care coordinator and was not offered any beneficial therapy and was lucky to see a psychiatrist on three occasions in over a year. When she moved to Cardf last summer she registered with a GP in the hope of being referred to their CMHT. I stressed to my GP that I needed crisis intervention, support in place and help regarding my food intake, she said.  I finally had an assessment which I believed went okay. I was struggling to consume anything more than a small meal and cups of coffee daily. I also felt very physically unwell, which is something my BMI wouldnapost tell the assessors.  Weeks after being weighed at her GP surgery, a part of the assessment she knew was required, she received a letter by Links Centre CMHT based at Cardf Royal Infirmary. It stated that Sammyaposs BMI was . which, despite still categorising her as underweight, meant she wasnapost eligible for support. Instead the CMHT recommended she seek support from Cardf University where she was studying. If eating disorder support is based on BMI, then why was I helped and accepted under one eating disorder service for seven months , but discharged back to my GP in the other   There are so many inconsistencies from one health board to another, despite them both being so close in proximity. In response, Cardf and Vale University Health Board said: We are sorry to hear that the patient felt that she did not get the support she needed from the mental health team. “Cardf and Vale UHB provides mental health services for people with eating disorders which covers the whole range of the body mass index . “There are a number of specialist multi-disciplinary teams who provide support and treatment for iniduals with eating disorders. The team works together to make decisions on inidual cases and practitioners use a range of risk factors such as psychiatric co-morbidity as well as physical health and BMI to determine what part of the service is most suitable for the inidual. “If the patient wishes to discuss any aspect of their care further we would ask them to contact our concerns team.”A campaign, called  Dump the Scales , was launched last summer which calls on services to judge eating disorder patients on their mental state, not their physical weight.It wants governments across the UK to fully implement NICE guidelines through GP and clinical training to ensure those with eating disorders get treatment before they reach crisis point. Hope Virgo, who spearheaded the campaign, said: When asked to imagine someone suffering with an eating disorder, most will imagine a stick thin, gaunt looking girl. But this is not the reality of eating disorders. People with eating disorders are currently not getting a fair deal in society. Despite the guidance, too often iniduals are turned away from receiving essential support because they aren’t skinny enough to be considered at risk. This leaves the inidual feeling like they aren’t worth getting that support, feeling like a aposfakeapos, potentially losing more weight to hit that target and in some cases feeling suicidal. This is why I’m calling on governments to review the eating disorder guidance delivered by clinicians. The NICE guidelines are right but these are not being unormly implemented across the nation to the detriment of thousands of people daily. It is time we stopped waiting for people to hit crisis point before offering them support. In response to the Dump the Scales campaign, a Welsh Government spokesperson said: “To support improvements to eating disorder services, Welsh Government commissioned Dr Jacinta Tan of Swansea University to conduct an independent review of the eating disorders framework for Wales. Dr Tan submitted her findings in November and a focused consultation is being planned to inform future actions which will build on the £.m we invest annually to improve eating disorder services for adults and children.”For help regarding an eating disorder, contact the eating disorders Beat on    or www.beateatingdisorders.org.uk

Like most five-year-olds, our girls are obsessed with Disney and we feel this would be the best way to communicate some important values. We know this isnapost a normal request for nannies, however it would be a great way to teach our girls about things like determination, compassion, fearlessness and ambition from strong yet relatable female role models like Princess Tiana, Princess Anna, Belle and Cinderella. So, how do they react to criticism that not all Disney characters imbue the qualities they are seeking, such as Sleeping Beauty and Cinderella who portray weak women who need rescuing by a Prince Charming  Honestly, before having children, I wouldnapost have known anything about this, but after seeing what seems like a million Disney films I can understand this, says the girlsapos dad.  Despite some older films needing a prince to save the princess, the woman is always the protagonist and holds the values we hope to teach our girls so this isnapost a big problem for us. I think the other parents will think weaposre crazy but hopefully will agree that itaposs a great idea to make the girlsapos days a bit more special - as well as teaching them great le lessons and values, their dad says. Most definitely, I think we will have a lot of girls wanting to come round to play. The girls are already devotees, says their father: We took the girls to Disneyland Paris last summer for the first time and I think it was the best week of their lives. They own a ridiculous amount of Disney toys and they probably have all of the princess costumes between them. We are planning to go to Florida next year too but the girls donapost know about that yet. We are hoping to surprise them and catch it on video. Are they looking for a real le Mary Poppins then  She is more than welcome to apply, says dad, laughing. Our girls have seen the movie and they love it, but I think they might be swayedit was between her or Elsa - sorry Mary! Real le princess Childrenaposs party organiser Lianne Cole understands the attraction of the Disney Princess for little girls. I have been doing princess parties for five years and I absolutely adore it, she says. I arrive at the door in a princess outfit and ask to come to the party. Seeing their young faces is an absolute joy. I organise games but the best part is the singing. I busk parttime at Covent Garden, so I have a big repertoire of songs. Naturally, I get asked to sing Let It Go from Frozen, which the children absolutely love. I have a microphone which I pass around and as you can imagine they all want to have a go. I have two other girls working with me sometimes and when we are together it is an absolute ball. There are so many princesses and so many stories there is a lot of material to draw on. Lianne, , who runs Southamptonbased Ever After Princess Parties is tempted to apply for the nanny role herself. If it wasnapost for the condition about being a nanny with two yearsapos experience I think I would apply, because it would be a fantastic job.

title: mum shares incredibly simple trick
story: NewsMum shares incredibly simple trick for saving sad-looking house plantsHouse plants have become increasingly trendy, but it seems not everyone knows how to take good care of themShareCommentsByCourtney PochinAudience Writer:,  MAR NewsA mum has revealed her simple trick for saving her droopy plants"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIf youaposre going to try and turn your home into a jungle, with leafy plants covering every free surface, then youaposve got to be prepared to look after your plants. You need to keep them watered, make sure theyaposve got enough light -  but sometimes even the most protective plant parent faces the heartbreak of losing one of their plants.But before you write it off and head to the garden centre to buy a new one, it might be worth trying one little trick first.   A mum from Australia has shared the very simple way she managed to revive her droopy and sad-looking plants. And all you need to do it is one very specic thing - epsom salts.In a post on Facebook she revealed that she gives her plants a bath and mixes in some of the salts.   She shared several photos of the plants, providing a before and after look to show just how much dference the magic ingredient made. The unnamed woman captioned the post: A few inches of water in the bath with Epsom salts and I give the leaves a shower to get dust etc off and keep it happy. She adds: I have to use themmyself and it was always sold out because gardeners would use it on their plants, thataposs what gave me the idea.    The woman went on to say that she usually uses about a handful of salts in a few inches of water and then leaves the plant to soak overnightitaposs looking particularly sad and dehydrated.A plant doctor toldthat Epsom salts could be useful for treating a plant with a magnesium deficiency - but added that most plants are droopy for other reasons, which wonapost be helped by the salts.It could be a case that you are giving your plant too much or too little water and need to adjust this accordingly. They recommend fully assessing your plantaposs symptoms before trying any home-remedies out yourself.

title: off grid couple dog save
story: NewsOff-grid couple and their dog save £k to build dream home by moving into a VANJane and Stephen Holmes gave up living in a house and moved into a VW van in the Scottish HighlandsShareByTom BallJane Lavender:,  MAR NewsJane and Stephen have moved into a van to save for their dream home "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA couple have managed to save £, towards building their dream home - by giving up city living and moving into a VAN. Marketing manager Jane Holmes and her husband, mountaineering instructor, Stephen, parked their long wheel base Volkswagen LT van in the Scottish Highlands. Jane worked remotely five days a week for a London-based tech company and both insist they miss nothing from their former le. The -year-old said: There was a lot of toing and froing before we decided to go and live in the van, while we considered what other people might think, as we knew there would be a stigma around it. We know it is unorthodox. We live in a world where everyone is trying to keep up with the Joneses, but we are the makers of our own destiny and we thought, aposWhy shouldnapost we  It makes total senseapos.    Jane and Stephen, , now live just outside the isolated Highland town of Fort William in their house on wheels with their Husky dog, Goose. The van is furnished with a bed, sofa and cupboards, along with an oven and portable toilet which they can empty, Jane and Stephen insist they miss nothing from their former le. Jane said: At first it was more dficult, not having a shower unless we went to a local gym and not being able to put the heating on after a wet day. But more and more we have learned to adapt to le in the van and I feel like I have everything Iaposve ever needed. I live in a place with stunning views, I have my health and my loving partner, and the ability to fit my working le around what works for me. What more could you want     After meeting  years earlier through Janeaposs sister, Joanne, , an adviser for BT, when Stephen was in the Royal Marines, the couple had their first taste of living in a van when they went on a four-month road trip around Europe in a Citroen Relay in . Jane, who had been working remotely from home in the coupleaposs rented house in Dundee, Angus, said: Steve and I both have the travel bug in us and had planned to do this trip for a while. I handed in my notice to my boss, but to my surprise he turned around and said, aposWhy do you need to quit  You could just work on the road apos And so she did, working two or three days a week while travelling through France, Spain and Portugal, using a portable Wi-Fi router to keep connected with her colleagues in the UK. She added: Having that flexibility with work made me realise that this was something you could do, and you didnapost have to necessarily be shackled to one place. That was what really planted the seed for everything that was to come. Returning home in December , the couple moved to a £ per month rented house in Fort William in early  to be closer to the Highlands, where Stephen runs mountaineering excursions.  They married in November . But, despite both working full-time, they calculated that it would take years of saving in order to buy the home of their own that they so desired, after renting for years. Jane said: Mortgages and deposits cost so much and it became clear after we married that weaposd have to really tighten our beltswe wanted any chance of buying a house. Then it occurred to us both that we could get around the problem by going to live in a van. We had done it before on our trip in Europe and knew that it worked for us, so we thought, aposWhataposs stopping us from doing it again apos Packing up their belongings in April , they bought a -year-old van big enough to fit a double bed in for £,, and leaving conventional living behind them, they headed to the Highlands. Explaining the situation to her boss at Cloudbooking, a meeting room booking , Jane was able to continue working in the same capacity as marketing and communications manager, despite living in a home with no access to water, electricity or gas. She said: In the st century, it doesnapost always make sense for everyone to be based in the same place when itaposs just as easy for people to work remotely with all the technologies we have today. Iaposm very lucky to have a boss who understands that and who gets that employee wellbeing is the most important elementsomeone is going to do a job well.  Living entirely off-grid for the first nine months, the pair braved the northern winter by keeping warm using a wood burner, showering at local gyms and powering up with rechargeable batteries. They provided around a fortnight of electricity, before the couple had to charge them again at friendsapos houses. But when in February  they stopped off at a holiday park a mile outside Fort William and were then offered a more permanent location by the parkaposs owners for £ per month, they decided to stay put, giving them access to the siteaposs electricity and washing facilities. Based there for almost a year now, they have saved two thirds of their £, target, with which they plan to buy enough land in the Highlands to build a three-bedroom house from stone. Jane thinks it will take them another  months to save the remaining £,. She said: It isnapost something that we would have been able to do otherwise at all. A lot of our friends and family thought we were mad at first, but then when you actually explain to people why it is that we made the decision, they start to understand and accept it as being a rational choice. In the summer we will be going to France for a two-month holiday, something weaposd never have been able to doweaposd been skimping and saving in rented accommodation. You canapost spend your whole time saving up your money because le is short and itaposs there to be enjoyed.

title: aberdeens delight at dundee and dundee united loan pair
story: The work of on-loan Tannadice Street temporary employees Scott Wright and Mark Reynolds has delighted their permanent boss Derek McInnes.In January, the Aberdeen manager loaned out winger Scott Wright to Dundee for the rest of the season and defender Mark Reynolds to Dundee United on a similar basis.He’s been monitoring their performances since and is more than happy with the reports he’s been getting.Wright has scored twice and had several assists in his seven games so far.And Reynolds’ form, as he recovers from major knee surgery he underwent after being injured during the pre-season build-up, has earned repeated praise from Tangerines boss Robbie Neilson, who’s made him captain.The Dons also let attacker Bruce Anderson head for Dunfermline.He’s been among the goals for the rejuvenated Pars and will be a threat to United’s promotion push when the teams clash down at East End Park on Tuesday night.“We have watched Mark, Bruce and Scott every game, either myself or one of the staff or scouting team,” said the Dons boss.“All three are contributing to their respective teams.“Scott is contributing well at Dundee and Mark is doing well at United, so long may that continue.”McInnes said he had discussed the pros and cons of Reynolds’ move to Tannadice before leaving the final decision with him.The Pittodrie manager said: “I spoke to Mark and he made the decision he wanted to go out on loan. We based it on the fact he was coming back from a serious injury and he had to go and play games. He has seen the benefit of that. For me, he is still our player.”McInnes is also delighted with the form of Anderson.“Wee Bruce is on fire. His report last week against Alloa was that he didn’t do a lot in the game but he took his goal brilliantly,” he said.“Since Bruce has gone down there, Dunfermline have gone right up.”McInnes or one of his staff will be in the stand at Tannadice tomorrow as Reynolds leads United out for their Championship clash with Alloa Athletic.

title: dundee cracks down on angus residents using city dumps
story: Dundee has slammed the brakes on Angus residents crossing the border to dump their rubbish in city skip sites.The withdrawal of the existing informal arrangement will now leave some rural residents facing a -mile round trip to Arbroath.The ban has reignited calls for an urgent reversal of a decision to stop Monieth and Carnoustie skip sites from accepting non-recyclable materials.Permits for vans and trailers being used to dispose of waste at the Baldovie and Riverside recycling centres will only be available for Dundee residents.Dundee City Council is urging people in Angus to “use the facilities provided by your local authority”.Angus councillor causes outrage by suggesting his residents should use Dundee dumps" src"https:www.eveningtelegraph fp angus-councillor-causes-outrage-by-suggesting-his-residents-should-use-dundee-dumps embed # secretEYcgeGly" data-secret"EYcgeGly" width"" "" title"#Angus councillor causes outrage by suggesting his residents should use Dundee dumps# # Evening " frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"Monieth and Sidlaw councillor Beth Whiteside said it was “clearly unacceptable” that Sidlaw residents would be left with a -mile round trip.She said: “I don’t blame Dundee for removing this facility –Angus is unwilling to formalise the arrangement and pay for the service, it is unrealistic to expect Dundee to subsidise them.“A new, fit-for-purpose centre to serve south Angus is the logical solution and I’ve asked that finding a suitable site becomes a priority in the development of the next local plan.“In the meantime, a general waste facility should be reinstated in Monieth Carnoustie.”An Angus Council spokesman said the authority would monitor the situation but decisions on the provision of waste facilities in Dundee were a matter for the city council.He said: “Our focus on increased recycling and more efficient use of our people, equipment and premises is key to delivering savings while retaining recycling centres in all seven Angus burghs.”

title: dundee fc apologises over incident involving irish flag being taken from celtic fan
story: Dundee FC has released a statement following an incident in which an Irish flag was taken from a Celtic supporter.Posts showed a steward apparently reaching up and grabbing the flag as it was draped over an advertising hoarding above the tunnel as Dundee played hosts to Celtic at Dens Park.A club spokesman said the manner in which the flag was taken was #not acceptable# and blamed a #communication breakdown# for the incident.mdash Adam O#BrianMarch , Stewards were seen to take the flag in a Twitter post, and a separate video showing an argument in the tunnel was also uploaded to the social media site.mdash Stephen Roberts 🍀March , A spokesman said: #The club would advise that the enquiries into the #flag# incident which took place at Sunday’s match vs. Celtic are now concluded.#These enquiries have revealed a clear breakdown in communication and decision making and moving forward, this needs to be and will be addressed by the club in conjunction with all members of the event management team.#Clearly, the method employed to remove the item from the advertising board was not acceptable and out with the agreed procedures for dealing with matters of this nature.#The clubs and the two supporters involved have met and discussed the issue at greatand Dundee Football Club would wish to convey our sincere thanks for the cooperation of all concerned.#In the spirit of the discussions which took place at this meeting, Dundee Football Club would wish to place on record our sincere apologies to the two supporters involved in this incident.#We will always endeavour in future to strive to achieve a safe and secure environment for everyone here at the Kilmac Stadium at Dens Park.#

title: dundee supporters society rejects bid from club owner to buy groups shares
story: Dundee’s main supporters group have knocked back the latest offer from the club’s American owner to buy shares from them and increase his stake at Dens Park to over %.But while they’re unwilling to sell any of their shares, the Dundee FC Supporters’ Society have repeated support for plans to move to a new stadium near the city’s Camperdown Park.In January, Texas-based Tim Keyes, through majority shareholders in the Dark Blues Football Partners Scotland which he owns, had a move to buy the society’s ‘A’ Ordinary shares refused.They’re the shares that hold the power of veto over such matters as any sale of the club, a move from Dens and even substantial borrowing.Earlier this month Keyes then made an offer for the society’s Ordinary shares, a move that would give him .% of Dundee shares and the club said would allow them to claim Group Tax Relief to offset losses.After discussions with the club and their own membership, however, the society’s board have decided that’s a non-starter as well.In an alternative proposal, the club had asked the society to “agree to support resolutions which increase the club’s share capital and then allot shares specically to FPS”.That, too, however, has been rejected. The society board have now informed Dens financial director David Gray and their own members of the decision to hang on to all their shares.Given there’s no provision in society rules for the sale of any shares and their rejection of the original attempt to get their veto-holding shares, this latest move comes as no surprise, particularly as even an improved offer of £, for the ordinary shares was viewed as derisory by many members.Dundee are now likely to undertake a full share issue that would allow Keyes to break through the % barrier but is likely to entail administrative costs running into five figures.

title: dundee united confirm departure of laurie ellis
story: Dundee United have confirmed former assistant boss Laurie Ellis’ departure from Tannadice.As the Tele revealed at the time, the former Raith Rovers stalwart was put on gardening leave back in January.United made no comment at the time but, in a statement today, announced the -year-old is no longer their employee.“As we continue to review all areas of the club and put in place our plans for the long-term vision we have for Dundee United, Laurie leaves with our thanks for his effort and commitment during his near-three seasons at Tannadice and our best wishes for his future coaching career,” said sporting director Tony Asghar.Ellis arrived at Tannadice as No  when Ray McKinnon was appointed manager in .He continued in that role under Csaba Laszo and for the first three-and-a-bit months of Robbie Neilson’s reign.“I am proud and honoured to have played a role at Dundee United,” he said today.“This is a fantastic club that has the potential to be in the Premiership and, while I wish that could have been achieved in my time here, I wish everyone at United all the best in their pursuit of promotion.“I now look forward to the next stage in my career.”Earlier this month reserve team manager Craig Easton and U  coach Scott Robertson were also stood down from their duties.To date, United have not commented on their situations.

title: dundee united hope to have pawlett and connolly fit to take on alloa
story: Dundee United boss Robbie Neilson is hopeful quick decisions to get injury doubts off in midweek will see two key men available for the clash with Alloa tomorrow.Peter Pawlett and Mark Connolly were both subbed early in the second half of Tuesday’s win over Ross County because of muscle tightness and Robbie revealed that was done with an eye on this weekend and beyond.“If you push them too hard you end up with tears and they could be out for the season. That’s why we took Pawlett and Connolly off as soon as possible,” he said.“They’ve both been feeling tight but it’s nothing serious and we think they’ve a chance of making Alloa.”Longer-term injury Freddy Frans is back from a trip home in Belgium for treatment on his groin tear. That’s helped but the defender remains some way off a .“Freddy went back to Belgium for a couple of weeks because he’s got a physio out there he uses and we felt he could go there, get a bit of work done on the injury and get back home to see the family.“He’s back now. To be honest, we might get him for the last couple of games at a push but it will be a long shot.”Returning to tomorrow, the manager admitted the mission is simple – do whatever it takes to get the three points and build pressure on leaders Ross County.“As long as we get the win, that’s it, whether it’s the first minute or the th.“This will be a dferent game to Ross County.“They are quite expansive and the full-backs push on, with Alloa they will sit in and that will be a dferent challenge.“Alloa are decent and, like the majority of teams that come to Tannadice, it’s a big day out, a big scalp.”

title: licensing board told reading rooms nightclub in better shape after management change
story: The new management at a local nightle institution has been praised for improving its standards.Bosses at the Reading Rooms on Blackscroft were given a cautiously warm reception at a meeting of the Dundee City licensing board following months of police interventions at the nightclub.Officers had placed restrictions on the Rooms after apparent evidence of cocaine use at the club emerged.But since then club manager Grant Grieve has surrendered his personal licence and has left.He is now transferring the licence to businessman Marc Sivewright, who now runs the business alongside Grant’s brother Jim.A police representative told the licensing board this week that there had been a change for the better.She said: “There were three incidents in relation to poor management between October  and December .“The incidents related toGrieve being hostile to police. Staff followed officers and filmed them – they were apparently instructed to do so by Mr Grieve.“On December  Mr Sivewright started and since there have been  inspections and three incidents. Staff and door staff have been supportive of police – but our concern is thatMr Sivewright leaves they will go back to their old ways.”However, Jim Grieve told the meeting efforts were under way to ensure the club does better.He also rubbished claims made in an online petition last year that the club was under pressure to close because of the “gentrication” of the area.He said: “Grant now has nothing to do with the business.“It was a third party that put that petition up and the moment we saw it we said it had to come down.“It’s nothing to do with ‘gentrication’. It was to do with incidents that happened at the venue.“We’re happy to work with Police Scotland and they are welcome at the venue any time.”As it is, the Reading Rooms can continue to trade. Licensing convener Stewart Hunter has opted to adjourn the venue’s case until a meeting in May to “make sure the good work continues”, at which point its future will be reviewed.

title: mum launches fundraising drive to give smiling riley the life he deserves
story: The mum of a severely disabled young boy has launched a £, fundraising campaign to pay for what she hopes will be le-changing treatment.Riley Welsh was born with brain abnormalities from microcephaly – a condition which stems from the skull being small and impacting brain development – that has left him immobile and non-verbal.Despite the challenges he faces, mum Leigh, , says he is rarely seen without a beaming smile on his face.#He is the happiest wee treasure and I am so proud of him,# she said.Riley was also born with a trachea-oesophageal fistula, which meant his oesophagus wasn’t attached to his stomach, rendering him unable to swallow food.He also has a feeding tube and colostomy bag and has a minor hole in his heart.Riley, , who goes to Kingspark School, is also epileptic, has severe developmental delay and is blind and deaf.Leigh, from Coldside, said her son’s condition is potentially le-shortening and recently Riley has been suffering from up to  seizures a day, many of which can last up to  minutes.Leigh is now seeking funding to pay for ABR therapy – a rehabilitative, home-based treatment that uses gentle hands-on methods to bring about recovery of the muscular skeletal system. ABR techniques are designed to strengthen the child’s core, increase strength, reducing spasticity and improving al ability.She said: “He had his initial assessment for the treatment earlier this month. We learned dferent techniques and exercises that we are going to practice at home. It’s very natural and relaxing and not aggressive or painful at all.“This is going to make Riley a happier and healthier little boy so I have launched a fundraising page to try to help find the money for this to continue.”To make a donation to Riley’s fundraiser visit justgiving crowdfunding riley-welsh.

title: on the scrapheap sorry end for kengo kumas slessor gardens pavilion
story: Plans to delicately move Kengo Kuma’s wooden pavilion out of Slessor Gardens are in pieces – after demolition workers were spotted lobbing it into a skip.Staff from Safedem, based in Lf Road, were spotted tearing the Japanese architect’s mini masterpiece to bits and throwing them in a skip this week.Constructed in  using wood from wind-felled trees in Templeton Woods, the pavilion was meant to be moved back to its source to be used as a bicycle hub on a biking trail.However, those plans now appear to have been quite literally thrown on the scrapheap.The Tele understands the plan to transfer the pavilion hit a snag after Safedem workers – who had been commissioned to prepare the building for transportation to Templeton – discovered the wood was rotting. It is believed a failure to properly fix the plastic roof to the pavilion allowed rainwater to get at untreated wood inside.The pavilion had been built to Kengo Kuma’s specications by staff in Dundee and shown off at the Pop-Up Cities Expo in Edinburgh in .It was then transported to Slessor Gardens, where it was used for events such as the annual Light Night festival.Mr Kuma, who designed VA Dundee, had created the pavilion as a way of telling the story of Dundee’s ongoing regeneration.Former city development chief Mike Galloway said in June  that those who visited the pavilion “will be able to learn how our waterfront is being transformed”.References to the pavilion have been removed from Dundee Waterfront’s website.A page on the site that once celebrated the m x m build now reads: “Access denied.”The apparent failure to properly care for the pavilion was branded “an absolute waste” by one local resident, who declined to be named.He added: “I was walking by and saw them throwing it all in the skip.“It didn’t look like it was in any fit state to go back together.”Safedem declined to comment. Dundee City Council was also approached for comment.

title: some michelin workers to get redundancy packages of more than 110000
story: Long-serving Michelin staff in Dundee will receive six-figure sums from the factory’s closure.The minimum that Baldovie staff stand to get under the enhanced redundancy package is about £,, with the biggest likely to be in excess of £,.Unite said it is a “very good deal”, but stressed the union’s priority is to ensure the site retains skilled jobs and every worker who wants it finds suitable employment.Senior shop steward Marc Jackson, who has been at the factory for more than three decades, said: “The deal we have on site, some say they’ve never seen a deal like it in the UK. But our best work is still to come,” the -year-old added. “That is to repurpose this site and get our members jobs.”The  workers there will receive . weeks of pay for each year service, up to a maximum of  years.It is assumed for the calculation that every worker has been there for at least five years.They are also getting bonuses, including at least £, for performance, another £, for recognition of service and a lump sum of £,, which was paid in January.A loyalty payment could be worth several thousand pounds for those who have been employed at the tyre factory for several years.Support for training and finding a new job includes a fund worth an average of £, to each person and extra time off, which is paid.There are also redundancy packages for apprentices.

title: tickets to see john torode and spencer matthews at taste of grampian set to go on sale
story: The countdown is on for a chance to see celebrity chefs including John Torode in action at this year’s Taste Of Grampian – and fans are being urged to get in fast.Tickets for demonstrations by John and other well-known MasterChef faces such as reality TV star Spencer Matthews and Scotland’s National Chef Gary Maclean are expected to be snapped up when they go on sale on Thursday.Carol Fowler, managing director of Prime Event Management, organisers of Taste Of Grampian, said: “Last year, tickets for James Martin sold out in under an hour. title: work progresses on new drive thru mcdonalds in north east town
story: Work is progressing on a two-storey fast food drive-thru restaurant in a north-east community.McDonald’s is currently building the new eatery at Portlethen Retail Park.The outlet was given approval by Aberdeenshire Council in June last year.The restaurant was part of an application that would see a six-pump petrol station and click-and-collect lockers on the site.Asda finished an upgrade to its petrol station after a three-month closure last year.It is not known when the new outlet will open but signage and the main structure have been completed.Around  full-time and part-time jobs will be created when it opens its doors.Concerns had been raised regarding antisocial behaviour and a potential increase in litter by members of the community.However, McDonald’s has assured the Portlethen and District Community Council that it will send out its own clean-up teams.

title: letters week 06
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSirWe would like to take this opportunity to thank all of those who have either given or offered assistance and support to my family following the fire at our home on the night of January , and a special thanks to the emergency services that attended.Anyone who was present either at the time or who has seen the remains will appreciate the level of destruction wrought upon our home and the contents within, however, as noted in this paper last week, all of us were unharmed and have been provided with accommodation nearby.The support given by friends, work and the wider community has been truly humbling, and as a family we thank you all and look forward to ing to our home, hopefully sometime next year.Thank you,Alan and Gillian Pitman, The Old Church, ArdrishaigSir,I must commend our MP Brendan O#Hara on his vision and wisdom on his recent fact-finding trip to the Faroe Islands to see first hand how The Faroese inter-connect their islands with  subsea and through mountain tunnels.This common sense approach guarantees safe connectivity   in any weather providing confident travel which is the least the people of Mid Argyll, Kintyre, Islay and Jura should expect. This area of Argyll is the most fragile in the region. The people of Argyll, businesses and visitors deserve no less.Forget the squandering of £m on unreliable, mitigation measures trying to justy a flawed decision made many years ago to use the Old Military Road as a ersion which has failed on many occasions and now has a landslip between the two roads. Forget the expensive excavation of pits by the A rather use the cuttings into the hillside to form a two lane road protected with a flow over canopy with closed outer edges at the four problems gullies. If the contractors on the present scheme can work without any road closures then the flow over canopy option would not lead to closures as many officials and some politicians claim.This is a red herring postponing #a proper solution#. When this is option is completed it will save on the expense of manning the ersion route involving - personnel and - vehicles, replacing expensive nettings, delays whilst the farmer clears his animals and collect his fees. A scandalous waste of public money. Solve The Rest Landslides and stop wasting on mitigating measures.Like Brendan O#Hara I#m neither an engineer or geologist but both of us are blessed with plain common sense. If the Faroese can build a tunnel at £.m per kilometre surely a simple open sided m canopy would cost considerably less. In  at Dawlish .km of double tracked railway and .km of sturdy seawall was built at a cost of £m in eight weeks. Why have we in Argyll after nine years, four dferent Transport Ministers and £m spent and still have no guaranteed safe passage   on The Rest and Be Thankful Follow the Argyll Advertiser#s campaign #Invest in the Rest#. Transport Minister Michael Matheson, Transport Scotland and our Government must abandon their obsession with mitigation measures and fund a permanent solution. We demand no less.Sir,Calls for assurances that the Rest and Be Thankful section of the A will be improved to resist future landslides were made during a session of Transport, Infrastructure and Connectivity questions in the Scottish Parliament.I quizzed transport secretary Michael Matheson, about what was discussed at the last meeting of the A Taskforce in November , and asked what assurances the Cabinet Secretary could give to local residents and businesses who rely on the A being open at all times.The Rest and Be Thankful was closed off for nine days in October  following the largest landslide in a decade, forcing road users to either take a major ersion, or to use the Old Military Road during certain hours of the day.A number of petitions were created during the period of the incident, including one by myself, calling for a permanent solution to the Rest and Be Thankful.The transport secretary said that the meeting was #full and frank#, and that there would be a #review of the potential for additional landslide mitigation measures at the Rest and Be Thankful#, and that this would be discussed at the next A Taskforce meeting in March .There was also a commitment that Argyll and Bute would be #prioritised# in the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.I welcome the assurances by the transport secretary that there will be a review of any additional measures for the Rest and Be Thankful, and that Argyll and Bute will receive priority at the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.Donald Cameron, MSPReserve forcesSir,Last issue#sletter raising concerns about the UK government’s proposed use of the army’s reserve force in the event of a no-deal Brexit is timely.In case anyone out there still thinks a no-deal Brexit is a good idea it’s worth noting that the legal authorityof Reserve Forces Act  allowing the Secretary of State to take this step requires him to establish that it is necessary #for the alleviation of distress or the preservation of le or property in time of disaster or apprehended disaster#.Enough said.Frances Roberts, Ardrishaig

title: honours even for red star in argyll derby
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowThe Ropework played host to this keenly contested local derby which was watched by a healthy crowd on Saturday February .And for the second time this season, Red Star and Campbeltown Pupils shared the points in a match both sides will feel they could have won.Both sides were struggling for fluency in the opening stages but Red Star settled first and grabbed the opening goal after  minutes. A long ball to the right hand side was met by Ryan Caskie who cut the ball back to Stuart McLean. The youngster took a touch before slotting past the Pupils# goalkeeper to give Star a - lead.Star continued to press and doubled their lead when Coll McCallum robbed the Pupils# defender on the edge of the box before cutting the ball across goal. The unfortunate Pupils# defender could only ert the ball into the empty net, with McLean waiting on a tap in. The game continued at a frantic pace, however, there was no further scoring in the first half and Star went in with a - advantage.Pupils came out with purpose in the second half as they looked to force themselves back into the game, however, it was a howler from Red Star which allowed them back into the match.A square ball across the back resulted in a mix-up between Star keeper Luke Kalache and defender Ben Forbes which allowed Donald McCallum to prod the ball home from just inside the box and Pupils were back in the game at - with eight second half minutes gone.The home side didn’t recover from this and you could sense a nervousness that gave the visitors plenty encouragement. The equaliser arrived with  minutes remaining when good play from Pupils down the right by Soudan saw him get a low cross in which was met by the on-rushing run of Ryan Deans and he finished well to level the score at -.This set up a frantic finish and both sides could have nicked it towards the end. Pupils went close with a headed effort which was clawed to safety while at the other end there was a goalmouth scramble which Star couldn’t convert and both sides had to settle for a draw in the end as referee Jimmy Litster blew for full time.Red Star were dealt a blow as it emerged that captain Aaron Moore suffered a dislocated shoulder. Hopefully this will not keep him out for too long.On Saturday February , Star have another important home game as they look to move off the bottom of the table when they take on Claremont AFC. title: john crawford ardrishaig
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowShinty in Mid Argyll has lost one of its great stalwarts with the passing of John Crawford of Ardrishaig after a short illness.John, aged , died in Mid Argyll Hospital on the evening of Thursday February .John was born and brought up in Minard in Argyll. He was a former member of shinty#s South of Scotland area executive council and did a lot of work for the Referees’ Association.He was probably best known for his work with young players in Mid Argyll, organising qualying tournaments of the Aviemore Indoor Sixes tournament for many years. His work for that competition was recognised by the organisers when he was given a special award at Aviemore along with his friend Donnie MacKenzie of Lochaber.John helped reform Kilmory shinty club in the mid s along with Ian MacPhee, the late Kenny MacRae, Roddy Munro and Alex Campbell. He also served on their committee for many years.John had served as a policeman for a short time before working in the quarry at Furnace, then going on to be a very well-known driver with Gleaner Oils, which supported many of his shinty activities with young players in Argyll.John was a great organiser and acted as goal judge in a number of senior shinty finals including the Glasgow Celtic Society Cup and notably the Camanachd Cup Final in Inverness when Gordon MacIntyre of Oban Camanachd scored his famous winner at the Bught Park.John apparently retrieved the ball from the net and lobbed another onto the park for the re-start before presenting the goal-scoring ball to Gordon after the match.John is survived by his brother Jim who played for Glasgow Police and he was pre-deceased by his we Donella. As a couple they were permanent fixtures at most shinty events in Argyll and well beyond, particularly at events involving young players.Tribute reproduced courtesy of the Camanachd Association

story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowThe latest artist to feature in the Dochas Centre in Lochgilphead is Tarbert#s artist and Argyllshire Advertiser#s contributor, Ann Thomas.Known on the Argyllshire Advertiser#s pages for her thoughtful and humorous depictions of Mid Argyll issues, Ann has been painting and selling images of the shores of Loch Fyne for years.Ann said: #I went to art school, then was a lecturer and got married, and in those days it wasn#t common for a woman to work and be married so I let the painting go for a while, until we found this derelict building that is now the Fyne Gallery.#We did it up and I started painting again and with a printing machine nearby we made a business of selling my paintings called the Ann Rose Thomas gallery: ART Gallery.#Ann#s paintings mostly focus on the water and nature surrounding Loch Fyne.Ann said: #Most of my paintings are bright and cheerful. The lights and the clouds change so the painting evolves as you paint.#The painting, Winter Sparkle on Kilbrannan Sound, hanging above the reception desk at the Dochas Centre is the first thing your eye sets on, and keeps you there with a subtle hint of glitter.#That was a bit tongue in cheek,# Ann said. #I didn#t want it to look like a Christmas card. title: thought for the week march 22 2019
story: Hannah OHanlonUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowAs a very enthusiastic, though amateur, photographer, I had treated myself to a new and rather expensive camera lens.Usually I purchase an inexpensive skylight filter to protect the lens from scratches or damage.The theory being that it is far easier and less expensive to replace an inexpensive filter than a very expensive lens.However I was intrigued when I began to research the best filter for my requirements.I was being offered a completely clear glass filter for way more than I would normally pay for a simple skylight filter.At first I thought: #Why on earth would I pay such a lot of money for something which is just a piece of clear glass #However when I read the reasons given to purchase this clear piece of glass, I was convinced.The logic was this – why pay a lot of money for a top-class lens, and then put a cheap filter on it Why not let the lens do the job you have paid it to do, and simply protect it with the finest clearest glass you can get.I thought of the words of St Paul who said: #For now we see through a glass, darkly but then face to face: now I know in part but then shall I know even as also I am known.#Somehow my clear glass filter gives me the best image reproduction I can have.In our earthly le, we see Jesus as best we can, perhaps through a skylight filter, but just think that in time there will be nothing to dull our vision and we will see him in all his glory # crystal clear and face to face.

title: ayr rugby club near move
story: NewsAyr Rugby Club near move to new town centre base at Dam Park as they prepare to sell Millbrae homeThe Millbrae men, who top the Tennents Premiership, are in advanced talks to sell their Millbrae home and move to Dam Park in Ayr town centre.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  OCT NewsDam Park could play host to Ayr Rugby Club as soon as  "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBooming Ayr Rugby Club are nearing a deal to sell their Millbrae home and move to the town centre. Plans to buy council-owned Dam Park are at an advanced stage. The club, currently top of the Tennent’s Premiership, hope the bold switch will take them to the next level. Ayr would earn a multi-million pound jackpot by hiving off their own land for housing, with builder Cala Homes believed to be preferred bidder for the site. And they plan to use part of the cash for a £, synthetic surface to be laid at their new home. Club chiefs have spent the last year in talks over a move and hope to seal the deal soon.  If the switch is rubber-stamped by South Ayrshire Council Ayr could be playing out of Dam Park as early as . One source said: “It is the move that makes sensethe club is to continue growing. “Next season sees the start of the Super Six set-up with games to be broadcast live on television. “It is potentially a great  for Ayr and bringing the club into the heart of the town can benefit so many.” The switch would see Ayr Seaforth Athletic Club on the move to a new sporting centre planned for Craigie. And junior side Whitletts Victoria couldto the heart of their community with a revamp of the old activity complex on the cards. Ayr rugby supremo Billy McHarg said talks on the move are progressing well.  He said: “Discussions to this point have been positive. “We’re keen to work with all parties to find the right solution and one which will benefit the whole town. “We feel that Ayr Rugby Club coming into the town centre would be a big step forward.” Club members would still have to approve such a move. Ayr have been at scenic Millbrae since . Prior to that they played out of Newton Park, Dam Park, the Old Racecourse and King George V playing fields. Whitletts chairman John Dalton said: “Talks have been very positive and we are currently looking at alternative options. “The football park at Whitletts is the obvious route to go down and would represent ahome to our roots. “A lot of water is still to go under the bridge but as Ayr’s junior football club we are viewing this as a positive opportunity.” Craigie councillor Ian Cavana said: “It may be that a deal is close but nobody will be moving anywhere until the new sports centre at Craigie is up and running. “Work is due to start on that next summer and that’s when we should see real progress.” A council spokesman said: “Discussions on the future of Dam Park are ongoing.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnSouth Ayrshire CouncilAyr NewsAyrAyr Rugby

It is understood ScotRail staff will neverto the dangerous building. It is believed they are to be housed in new portable cabins across the railway line at empty ground on Station Road. The option of a new new transport hub being built in the vicinity of Burns Statue Square has been mooted in the past. But no solid plan has emerged. Councillor Campbell said: “We maintain dialogue with the Scottish Government, Transport Scotland and Network Rail about future investment at the station. title: gran who hurled bleach over
story: Picture by contracted freelance Steve McKendrick"Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA gran who hurled bleach over a child has been granted a personal licence to sell alcohol by East Ayrshire council. Mary McLelland was convicted of throwing the cleaning agent over a -year-old boy’s head and body in Auchinleck. Police objected to McLelland getting a personal licence at the council’s licensing board meeting heard last week, McLelland, , of Main Street, Auchinleck carried out the crime in November . Police Sergeant David Dougan told councillors McLelland was sentenced to a community payback order at Ayr Sherf Court last year as punishment. But McLelland said she was plagued by anti-social behaviour outside at her home in Main Street. She told the board: “I love kids. I regret it.” She claims she has had problems with people “chapping her door” and urinating in her garden. She rushed out to the nearby bus shelter during one incident, she told the meeting.. McLelland said: “I went out. It wasn’t even raw bleach. It is not an excuse. I shouldn’t have done it.” She claimed the bottle was kicked out of her hand and spilled over the victim. But the meeting heard McLelland pled guilty in court. The shop worker said: “I am not in the habit of going out and fighting with kids. “I am a -year-old woman.” She added: “Everybody in this le makes mistakes. Nobody in this world is perfect.” She told the meeting she had phoned the police numerous times to report anti-social behaviour at her property. Councillors adjourned the meeting to discuss whether she should be handed a licence. Ontheir opinion was split with three councillors voting to grant her application and the same number against. Board Chair Councillor Tom Cook had the ruling say and decided to grant McLelland’s licence. He said giving her the licence would not increase her chances of committing a similar offence in the future. Councillors George Mair, John Campbell and Fiona Campbell voted to refuse the licence. Councilors Drew Filson, Lillian Jones supported Councillor Cook’s view to grant it. Councillor Cook said he would grant the licence “albeit with reservations.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnEast Ayrshire CouncilCourtsJusticeAyr

title: people say future high rise
story: NewsPeople to have their say on the future of high-rise flats in AyrTenants asked for their preferred optionShareByGary Fanning:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR News"Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTenants in the Riverside Place multi-storey flats in Ayr are getting the chance to have their say on the future of the high-rise properties as South Ayrshire Council’s consultation on ‘Your place, your future’ gets underway. The consultation and engagement exercise – approved by Councillors last year – gives tenants the chance to choose their preferred option for the long-term future of the flats: Refurbish  – this means the Council would keep the flats, decant tenants, carry out identied refurbishment works, and thentenants to their refurbished flats. Rehouse  – this means tenants would be rehoused permanently in suitable alternative accommodation and the flats would be demolished. Rebuild  – this means tenants would be decanted to temporary accommodation and the flats would be demolished before some tenantsto a new-build housing development on the Riverside Place site. The detailed consultation, which is based around inidual one-to-one meetings with more than  tenants, has been planned in conjunction with the River Ayr Tenants Association, which represents tenants in the three blocks. The Council has communicated regularly with tenants in the lead-up to the consultation to ensure they have all the information they need to take part. A further letter has now been distributed to homes in Riverside Place following queries and concerns raised by tenants regarding a letter sent to them by Fort, Seafield  Wallacetown Community Council. The community council’s letter appears to query the three consultation options being discussed with tenants and questions South Ayrshire Council’s interpretation of the expert report approved last year regarding the “essential and advisable” works required to the flats. Councillor Philip Saxton, South Ayrshire Council’s Portfolio Holder for Housing and Community Wellbeing, said: “We are committed to ensuring that our tenants are fully involved in the discussions about the future of their flats, which is why we’re taking such a detailed approach to this consultation. “It’s vital that tenants understand all the facts so they can form their own views about the option that is best for them. That is why we have gone back out to them to respond to the queries and confusion that have been generated by the community council’s letter. “We fully appreciate that the community council may have a view on the consultation, which is why colleagues are meeting with them next week and we’re happy to keep them informed about the consultation and engagement process. “However, our focus – which was clearly expressed by tenants at the recent River Ayr Tenants Association meeting – has to be on hearing the views of those who will be directly affected by Councillors’ decisions later this year: the tenants of Riverside Place. “We thank them for their participation in the consultation and I can reassure them that their views will be taken into account before any decisions are taken about the future of Riverside Place.” Joe Lafferty, Chair of the River Ayr Tenants Association, said: “We have worked closely with the Council over the last couple of years as discussions around the future of the flats have moved forward – and we very much appreciate the approach the Council has taken. “It is for every tenant to consider what is the best option for them and to ensure their voice is heard by those who will be making the decisions about what happens next. Clear facts, easy to understand information and answers to the questions tenants have is what’s needed and that’s exactly what we have got from the Council.”   Feedback from the consultation will be considered by Councillors in June this year.Full details of the Riverside Place consultation are available at  www.south-ayrshire.gov.uk riverside-place . title: plans luxury flats prestwicks malcolm
story: NewsPlans for luxury flats at Prestwicks Malcolm Sargent House are scrappedDevelopers have dropped their proposal to build on the famous site at the seafront.ShareByPaul Behan:,  MAR NewsArchitects plans for the retirement flats "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailPlans to build luxury flats at the former Malcolm Sargent holiday retreat for sick kids in Prestwick have been binned. The Post can exclusively reveal that the developers McCarthy  Stone have thrown in the towel and withdrawn their multi-million pound proposals. Major question marks hang over the building’s future following the bombshell announcement. The news prompted an angry backlash from Derek Hart, chair of Prestwick North Community Council. In an extraordinary outburst he claimed the building has been “plundered and left to rot.” The building provided a retreat for children battling cancer for more than  years. It was opened by Princess Diana in . In  it was sold by owners Clic Sargent after claims of a “challenging fundraising environment”. They sold it to McCarthy  Stone and trousered £.m from the deal. However, since McCarthy  Stone took ownership and unveiled their luxury flat plans they have been embroiled in a bitter fight with neighbours Prestwick Golf Club. The club was opposed to the development on the basis of its scale and design. Other objections included the potential impact it would have had on their historic course and the surrounding conservation area. In addition, there were fears that errant balls could smash into residents’ properties. Plans involved building  flats for people aged over , spread out in a T-shape over four floors. Many would have had sea views and balconies. The proposals were approved by South Ayrshire Council but last year Prestwick Golf Club successfully petitioned for a judicial review, meaning demolition work on the former retreat had to stop. It was estimated that  jobs would be created between the construction phase and posts at the new development. Despite a PR charm offensive from McCarthy  Stone throughout the process and a public exhibition of plans at the  Club in Prestwick’s Main Street, the developers pulled the plug on the project. A spokesperson said: “Following a strategic review last year we are no longer pursuing any new developments within Scotland and have withdrawn our plans for Prestwick.” Derek Hart reckons the decision is a kick in the teeth for all the campaigners who fought to retain the presence of a sick children’s home in Prestwick. He told the Post: “I find this action taken by McCarthy  Stone not only deplorable but a slap in the face to the Save Malcolm Sargent House team who fought bravely to try to purchase it. “Is it not time for South Ayrshire Council to stop and listen to the community  “The community stated that the development would only feather the nests of McCarthy  Stone – and perhaps chemists –as the age group targeted by them were over  years. “There’s been very little input to Prestwick and we are now left with a building that has been plundered and left to rot. “Will we find the same response to the other end of the beach, at the old Gym, I wonder ”He added: “Time after time SAC have allowed developers to build as they wish with barely a challenge to the character ofthe town and how it should look.”The news will be viewed as a major victory for Prestwick Golf Club, who fought long and hard against the development. A statement by the club said: “While we welcome this news we hope that, should a new development proposal for the site be put forward in the future, the design and scale will be more sympathetic to the surrounding area.” The statement said the club was not against the principle of redeveloping the site but was “disappointed” at the scale and design of the proposed development. It added: “We believed that McCarthy  Stone hadn’t listened to the concerns raised by the club.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnPrincess DianaSouth Ayrshire CouncilRoyal FamilyPrestwickAyr NewsAyr

title: sisters act sibling fiona stricken
story: NewsSisters Act for sibling Fiona, stricken by strokesThousands of pounds raised for Stroke Association by Prestwick pairShareByStephen Houston:,  MAR NewsAfter the race - Gaenor, Gillian and young Graham "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe strokes struck without warning to a lady in her prime. Super-fit Fiona McBlane was , practised yoga and cycled and was in London lapping up a glamorous working le in the music industry for companies such as EMI and Smash Hits. But during a Christmas visit home to Ayrshire she fell unwell with leg, arm and head pain. Such was her distress she admitted herself to hospital. First the minor stroke hit - on January ,  - and then the searing biggie nine days later. It left her semi-paralysed in hospital for  months, unable to speak, hardly walking and retaining very limited brain capacity. That was when Clan McBlane rallied round to give her the best future they could. They had been advised the best place for her was an old folks home but they stood firm. Once Fiona was fit enough to leave hospital she was brought into the bosom of the family in Prestwick. Twelve years on at the age of , Fiona is battling away and has got to the stage where she has joined the gym at Prestwick Tennis Club. Her loving older sisters Gillian McBlane, , and -year-old Gaenor Hardy have just pounded round the Stroke Association’s Resolution Run with Gillian’s -year-old son Graham to continue raising money for the charity. That added £ to a total now of about £. Gillian, a top civil lawyer in Ayr, and Gaenor, headmistress at Heathfield Primary, assist their parents Jean and Ian who are Fiona’s full-time carers. And Gillian is helped by the other legal eagle in the family, Ayr criminal defence agent Steven Maxwell. Gillian said: “She loved her work and was a real high flier. “People were drawn to Fiona’s fun-loving nature and her great big heart. “Never for a minute did we think she would have a stroke. “At  years old she had lost everything she loved.” Fiona is prone to falling and choking, often passing out. Sometimes the enormity of what has happened becomes too much for her and she struggles emotionally. But Gillian said: “Our parents taught us to look for the positive things in le and not to feel sorry for ourselves. We spend time together and Fiona enjoys the company. “Despite the extent of her disability, she does brilliantly. “Doctors told us that her friends would eventually tail off but Fiona’s haven’t . They keep in contact with her and visit when they can. “People have shown us great kindness over the years in so many ways and this means a lot, helping us immensely. We don’t know what the future will hold for Fiona but we do know that whatever it is we will face it together.” There are , strokes in Scotland every year. Angela Macleod at the Stroke Association said: “Our latest research shows that by training and taking part in a Resolution Run you are helping to lower your stroke risk. “The funds raised by each runner means we can reach out to more stroke survivors and their families to offer the support that they may need to rebuild their lives.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnstrokeAyrAyr NewsPrestwickRunningCharity

title: holy-moly-the-tour-ends-in-galashiels
story: A FEVERISH frenzy of folk, blues and indie is on the menu next month at the MacArts as Holy Moly  The Crackers bring their party to town.The Newcastle sextets stomping stage shows are quickly becoming legendary.And their latest release, Take A Bite, has propelled them towards even bigger and greater things this year.Led by the euphoric lead single, All I Got Is You, Take A Bite combines pop song craft with stomping, four to the floor backing, demonstrating Holy Moly  The Crackers commerciality and ambition, as well as their ability to tackle personal lyrical fare, deftly led by vocalist Ruth Patterson.Further adorning their naturally expressive take on British folk with sizeable dollops of rockrsquonsoul, sharp indie-rock, vulnerable balladeering and festival-ready psychedelic trips towards the Middle East, Take A Bite sets its stall confidently in the previously unoccupied space between the Gossip, Arctic Monkeys, the Bs and Gogol Bordello.Working once again with producer Matt Terry , the band ndash completed by Conrad Bird on vocals guitar trumpet, Rosie Bristow on accordion, Nick Tyler on electric guitar, Jamie Shields on bass and Tommy Evans on drums backing vocals ndash created Take A Bite at VADA Studios in Warwickshire.Holy Moly  The Crackers embark on their UK tour at Liverpools O Academy on April , taking in venues up and down the country.And they will bring the curtain down in Galashiels on Sunday, April  at the MacArts.Tickets are available now from the Box Office on  .

story: FIDDLE fans in Melrose were recently treated to an award-winning Scottish band perform earlier this monthContemporary Scottish fiddle band Blazinrsquo Fiddles entertained a big crowd at the Corn Exchange hosted by Live Borders.A spokesperson told us: ldquoBlazinrsquo Fiddles are one of the worldrsquos most prolic fiddle groups.ldquoNo other band has quite managed to capture the excitement, sensitivity and raw fire of Scottish music all at once.ldquoOne of todayrsquos foremost Scottish folk acts, Blazinrsquo Fiddles combine over  yearsrsquo experience with ever-renewed musical appetite, vitality and sophistication.Blazinrsquo Fiddles are currently celebrating their st year of touring and recording and show no signs of slowing down. story: DESPITE the weekends storms, over , visitors enjoyed this years Borders Art Fair - a  percent increase on last year.And more than pound, was spent on works by the regions leading contemporary artists throughout the event at Springwood Park.Over  artists, galleries and collectives took part, showcasing a selection of beautul works and inspiring and delighting visitors from the Borders and beyond.This yearrsquos Fair also included a series of talks by leading figures in Scotlandrsquos art world including VA Dundee director Philip Long and Scottish Gallery director Guy Peploe.The Fair organisers had also arranged a series of activities and workshops for children.And visitors were also able to enjoy artist-led workshops and demonstrations including figurative drawing and stone letter carving.Tours of the art and architecture of Borders historic houses, Mellerstain and Marchmont House, were full-booked throughout the weekend and an exhibition and print demonstration by the Royal Scottish Academy in Kelso Town Hall was also a popular addition to the  event.Borders Art Fair director Frances Fergusson told us: ldquoWersquore delighted that we were able to attract an additional , visitors to this yearrsquos event and are thrilled that the work on show was so well received."The aim of the Borders Art Fair is to engage and inspire people of all ages through amazing original work and itrsquos extremely rewarding to see their reactions as they enjoy the event and to be able to help support the incredibly talented artists who live and work in the Scottish Borders and surrounding areas.The Borders Art Fair is part funded by Awards for All, the Fallago Environment Fund, The Scottish Government and the European Scottish Borders LAG LEADER -
